job_title: Student Human Resources Assistant in San Diego, CA
pros: You will be given responsibilities from day one, and there is a large emphasis on ownership of responsibilities.  You won't pick up many hard skills transferable to other jobs, but you will grow in soft skills such as teamwork, communication, and responding quickly to requests.  Supervisors make sure that you feel like part of a family of coworkers.  Bonding events such as monthly birthday potlucks help create a team atmosphere, even though people belong to different functional groups and roles within the organization differ from person to person.  Work-life balance is great: almost never have to work overtime or weekends at the analyst level.  The experience varies a lot depending on who your supervisor is.
cons: There exists a very damaging culture of gossip among the employees.  Talking about others behind their backs is prevalent.  The work gets repetitive very fast.  Not a lot of upward mobility.  Work-life balance is worse at the management level, but you won't be promoted into such a position until many years into your tenure anyway.

job_title: Lecturer in San Diego, CA
pros: I love teaching here. Professional environment. Great students. Beautiful facilities. I have enjoyed working for this educational institution for over five years. There is growth in some departments, and no growth or little growth in others. Currently the entire higher education is under new legislation requiring an increase in graduation rates, which is negatively impacting many programs.
cons: A complete lack of diversity in the faculty of my department. They don't even see it, believing that they are "transparent," which is in itself a non-diverse perspective. Part-time lecturers teach 80% of undergraduate classes, but are kept at under 50% pay (me at 33% or below) so they don't have to pay us benefits. So after five years of working there and having some of the largest classes with the best reviews in my department, I get a guarantee of 33%, and don't have to re-apply for my part time position. It is disgraceful. I don't have any time to do research or advance my field in the way I originally intended when entering academia.

job_title: Staff Research Associate III in La Jolla, CA
pros:
The benefits are great (medical, dental, retirement)
La Jolla is beautiful (but expensive)
Academia atmosphere - not too many pretentious people; co-workers have great camaraderie 
Groundbreaking research being done 
Great pride in working at such a world renowned institution
cons: It may depend on which department you work for. I am with the ADCS (Alzheimer's Disease Cooperative Study) and for the most part, the work is very rewarding. What is lacking is great leadership and management skills amongst the upper level management (directors, etc. - there is a lot of "micromanaging"). Additionally, communication and training needs improvement. There is no structure and is a "learn as you go" environment which can be overwhelming with the amount of information you're "required" to know in this field. Sadly, there is a sense of nepotism within the small selective groups. Rumors of employees being treated unfairly in regards to promotions and merits. The once a month payday is also a big adjustment for some. Too much time being spent on meetings, which can slow down productivity. Lastly, the use of technology (MAC system vs. PC) might not be a transferable skill when going elsewhere.

job_title: Senior Technical Staff in La Jolla, CA
pros:
- Often (depending on job) flexible hours or telecommuting is possible, and not insane hours either
- Lots of different projects (many are Very Cool) and activities going on
- Reasonable possibilities to move from one position to the next
- IT support can be state of the art (or, not...)
- Great pension if you make it 5 years
- Nice after-hours pick-up games (soccer!) and activities
- Oh, the weather! Wow.
cons:
- Pay scale on the low side (very low compared to Silicon Valley, but not too bad for San Diego)
- You will have trouble getting ANY raises after you start, let alone reasonable ones
- Parking is expensive and not very convenient to some places (read: Atkinson Hall)
- Your mileage will vary according to your boss and your project; environment great or terrible accordingly
- The bureaucracy is moderately inept (occasionally brutally inept), so HR, IT, facilities support goes accordingly
- Poor bicycle access and accommodation (no showers in reasonably new buildings? seriously?)
- Hiring process is messy, no matter which side you look at it from
- They don't do well on the "abusive environment" questionnaire; it isn't inherently abusive, it's just unmonitored.
- Mentoring is not a university thing. Get over it.

job_title: Teacher in La Jolla, CA
pros: Working at this school can be challenging and rewarding at the same time.  The students are the best part and it's unusual to work at a school where parents are 100% behind the teachers.  I've worked at many schools where the parents blame the teachers for everything.  It's satisfying to know you are really making a difference in these kids' lives.
cons: Working for UCSD is very frustrating.  The charter school is on the UCSD campus and subject to the whims of the UC system.  Salaries are a joke.  They want to treat us like hourly workers at the student bookstore, not as the professionals we are.  We are also under the microscope of San Diego Unified School District.  They like to claim us as one of their schools when it suits them but ignore us when we need their help, such as with transportation or participating in teacher training.  Morale here is BAD. There are teachers actively looking to work elsewhere because the Board of Directors seems so opposed to supporting increased teacher pay.  The school year is 203 days, that's nearly a month longer than most schools in California.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in La Jolla, CA
pros: Beautiful location, possible networking opportunities, looks great on a resume
cons: Where to begin? Be prepared to be low balled during your negotiation upon hire, try to get as much as you can.   Parking is $81/month per paycheck and it is mandatory.  This is not disclosed until your new employee orientation.  Also, be wary of the show this place will put on to make you "feel" as though you're an important employee...you're not.  Depending on what department hires you, you will be surprised at how under qualified supervisors can be here.  It's problematic but even more so when you see them get promoted.  The high turn around rate is real here and you will most likely be put in situations that require you to rise above internal issues that were never addressed before your start so they just linger without resolution.   Most of the time, it isn't worth the pay here.   Almost 2 months into my new position and I was already looking for employment elsewhere.  Most disappointing is how low patient care is on the list of priorities here.  They do not make the health care process easy to understand for patients and have a tendency to cater to wealthier patients (see: Concierge services here).  Completely siloed on every level.

job_title: Director of Operations and Administration in San Diego, CA
pros: What can you say about a job that is right on the ocean of Southern California, other than "I am blessed to be here!"  A large University - rated in the top 10 of research institutions - is only overshadowed by the brilliant minds within academia that support it.   Nestled in the town of La Jolla, the working atmosphere mirrors the laid-back and easy lifestyle that is California.  The Senior Management Group is first rate, and truly support the success of all staff and faculty, so they can achieve great things with great students.  All of UC's 10 campuses are great, but UC San Diego holds that special appeal for those interested in advancing their careers in the best of settings.  UC San Diego is San Diego's largest employer, and is respected within the entire county.
cons: No cons...just big!  Big certainly brings issues, but all good learning moments for employees.  If you learn that here, then you can easily stand up to the likes of Donald Trump and Barry Diller...who I both dealt with in previous careers.  Back then, I lost the battles...today?  It's would be shooting fish in a barrel!

pros: Great benefits and opportunities for growth
cons: Occasional staffing issues and office politics,

review_title: Overall It is a nice place .
job_title: Staff Research Associate III in San Diego, CA
pros: Good Benefits including health insurance.
cons: various between different lab. Salary

job_title: Analyst in La Jolla, CA
pros: Flexibility in terms of scheduling, great management team
cons: no negatives that come across my mind

job_title: Anonymous Employee in La Jolla, CA
pros: A diverse community to work with.
cons: Heavy work load for students.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in San Diego, CA
pros: A good place to study
cons: campus buildings are so ugly

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in La Jolla, CA
pros: flexible, creative, reliable, cooperative, open-minded
cons: low-salary, salary is low, we need more money

job_title: Software Engineer, Intern in San Diego, CA
pros: Flexible scheduling for tutor hours
cons: No cons for tutoring at ucsd

job_title: PhD Candidate in San Diego, CA
pros: City has lots of amenities
cons: Low pay and high responsibility

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Diego, CA
pros: Very laid back and simple
cons: Hours can be hard to come by

job_title: Anonymous Employee in La Jolla, CA
pros: The insurance is solid and if you live near Hillcrest you can take a free shuttle to work. If you are working a job that is represented by either UAW (the union for grad student workers) or AFSCME (the union for maintenance and service workers), you have a strong, well-organized union that will fight for you.
cons: If your job is not covered by UAW or AFSCME, you are much more likely to shoulder the burdens of continual budget cuts—increased workload, stagnant wages, equally over-worked co-workers. The UC President still makes about $600k a year. If you aren't taking the shuttle, plan on spending hundreds of dollars a year for a parking pass and fighting with grad students and undergrads for extremely limited parking. At least once in the past five years, the administration was seriously investigated by the FBI for suspected violations of African Americans' civil rights. The racial climate on campus has repeatedly been described as "toxic". They hired the former head of Homeland Security as university president rather than somebody with actual educational experience. Make of that what you will.

review_title: Decent place for your academic career.
job_title: Graduate Researcher in La Jolla, CA
pros:
It's a very nice place for people who seeks for their career as a bio-related researcher. UC San Siego is a well-known/high-ranked institute in bioengineering and is well funded in this arena as well.

In addition, UC San Diego is located in La Jolla, CA, which is one of the best place in the US. It's a nice place to work, do research, and enjoy the life. Is there any other places which is better than this place ? I can hardly think of any one which tops UC San Diego.

For people who like to surf and do outdoor activities, it's the place!
cons:
Well, it is a nice place and you know, people in CA is a little bit laid back and they know how to enjoy their life. The pace is not as fast as the pace in some major cities such as Los Angeles, San Francisco, New York, etc.

Distance between the buildings are far away from each other so if you have to do experiments in different building in the same day you run into spending a lot of time finding parking spaces and traveling between labs. And Yes, parking in UC San Diego is terrible. Anytime between 9 am to 4 pm is difficult for you to find a parking space.

review_title: One horrible manager can ruin your entire experience
job_title: in La Jolla, CA
pros: There are a lot of resources and benefits. Most people had less uptight bosses so their experiences are better than mine. There are a lot of nice people working there.
cons: Parking is expensive, insufficient for demand, and far from where you want to go. Once you find a space, you can't move it or you'll never park again, so you have to walk everywhere anyway. If you're stuck with a mean, vindictive, uptight boss as I was, your life can be hell. A lot of people have no industry experience other than working for the university so they don't know industry terminology and procedures or just how the real world operates. If you think you'll be able to take free or cheap classes there, think again. They do everything they can to prevent people from using their educational benefits.

review_title: High turn around and no accountability
job_title: Research Coordinator in La Jolla, CA
pros: Benefits (though you pay for that through high deductions) and work flexibility (if you're an expert multi-tasker) & some of the doctors are great to work with
cons: Misguided or absent management, transferring 'problem employees' to other departments rather than releasing them, Union constraints/rules on everything from starting salary to promotions to yearly wage increases, parking is expensive and still not guaranteed, disregard for employee happiness in general, a pretty worthless HR/labor relations departments (any complaints about management are disregarded and retaliation for whistle blowers is real), an overall acceptance of verbal abuse from higher management as a way of life, and obvious nepotism

review_title: The Good, the Bad and the Ugly
job_title: Program Representative in La Jolla, CA
pros:
* The benefits are decent.
* There are a lot of smart, hardworking people on staff.
* You get to take free classes at Extension.
* The HR department has a soul (where many don't).
* Great job security...once you make it past your 6 month mark, it's very hard to get fired.
cons:
* Managers are hired based on academics, not management skills.
* Unhealthy, "tattletale" environment (e.g. whoever complains first is "right").
* The pay is low for the level of education required and raises are negligible.
* Staff members are frequently out on "stress leave" due to poor management of resources/time.
* Unwilling to invest in the infrastructure necessary to improve workload and atmosphere.
* Nearly impossible to fire anyone with clearly denoted workplace issues or lack of performance.
* Once you make it past your 6 month mark, it's very hard to get fired.

job_title: Programmer/Analyst I in Jonzac
pros: It's a stable job with well-defined requirements.  Being an educational institution, there is generally support for professional development in the form of connecting you with more experience people in the same function or other education opportunities.
cons: Seniority is king, merit is unrewarded, and underperforming employees languish forever in their jobs, wasting resources.  Top management is wasteful, unfocused, and unattentive.  Tight salary guidelines mean overspending on unproductive employees while failing to attract high-performers.  Dominance of part-time low-salary positions among line staffers means the workforce is divided between cushily-paid middle management with decades of experience and low-paid line employees who last about a year or two on average - very few people in between, there is no pipeline of professional development.

review_title: Varies by Department, Instructor, and Class
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in San Diego, CA
pros:
Some instructors organize their classes in such a way that makes it easy to do everything.

It can be a good experience if you're looking to go into teaching or enjoy teaching.

Typically leaves lots of time to focus on research or your own classes.

There's a large degree of flexibility in setting office hours and grading schedules. You get some say in choosing which professors you TA for.
cons:
Some instructors will overwork you.

Some students can be annoying.

Compensation varies by department, but is typically low and not keeping pace with rising rental rates.

You will have at least some negative student evaluation comments, no matter how good you are. Some of these will be unfair, rude, or derogatory. Student feedback can sometimes be unhelpful.

Grading is always at least semi-unpleasant.

job_title: Administrative in La Jolla, CA
pros:
I have been working part time per diem for over two years now with absolutely no benefits. If they allow me to convert to a career position, they STILL won't give me any benefits! 
UCSD doesn't even pay into Social Security. Instead they take 7.5% out of your paycheck and place into a Fidelity run fund that charges a monthly $35 service fee! You do not have access to the funds until you are no longer an employee of UCSD.  

No paid holidays, sick or vacation days. 

The wages here are so low. Same wages that I made over 20 years ago in other organizations. Seriously better off working at Trader Joe's or Starbucks which actually provides benefits to their part time employees.

They also charge employees for parking! Unless you start work at 7am, there is never any available parking nearby so you have a good 10-15 minute walk to add onto your commute. Especially not easy for employees who don't feel well yet aren't disabled to get a handicap permit.
cons: I love all the emails from UCSD Medical Center stressing the importance of healthcare “when you feel better, everything is better”, “live your better life” yet they can’t offer health plans to part time employees.

job_title: Executive Administrative Assistant in La Jolla, CA
pros: Benefits and employee resources are amazing. It's a large company so there are lots of opportunities to branch out but stay within UC. Beautiful campus. Hard to get fired.
cons: Parking is a major difficulty. Traffic in La Jolla and getting off campus has gotten increasingly worse in recent years. Usually getting a new position is all about "who you know" but that is true in a lot of places. It's hard for a supervisor to give you a raise without reclassifying which is a long process if they are willing to put in the effort. Recent HR changes hopefully will improve this. Sometimes a lot of red tape to walk around/under. Lower level positions are a dime a dozen and there is a lack of quality; great people move up quickly so those that stay in those positions are there for a reason.

job_title: International Travel Consultant in San Diego, CA
pros: Good and established team to work with
cons: Good people but very drama maker

job_title: Researcher in La Jolla, CA
pros: Decent benefits, decent work/life balance, casual dress, many on-campus food and cafe options, pay for attending seminars
cons: Low pay, high parking costs, researchers report what is politically convenient for them rather than what they actually find, no support or protection for whistle blowers with respect to research misconduct, individuals responsible for ensuring that ethical research practices are maintained are too politically invested to do their job, not a place one can do honest scientific research

review_title: Experience can be department, group dependent.   Effort to do great things though.
job_title: Project Manager in La Jolla, CA
pros: UCSD is very diverse from culture to professional background. There is a lot of great science happening all around us.  There is a true intent to build community and pride.
cons: In the two clinical trial groups I have worked, the academic/science pursuit is so strong, such that SOPs are seen as marginal guidelines and their maintenance too much of an effort.  People just know what to do in their heads because attrition is very low.  So sometimes, problem solving becomes stale because there are no new ideas. For personnel paid on grant money, grants may not get renewed and one would need to look for a new job.  People can get pigeon-holed accordinging to previous jobs.  HR does not see tranferable skills.  The key is to include the keywords from the job description into the resume.

review_title: Great place to work, great benefits IF you can get hired!
job_title: Temp
pros: quality of life; flexibility; contributing to global society; as an educational institution, there are many and countless opportunities to advance your skills; much of the staff education is available free of charge; if you start as a temporary employee, you have an advantage to get hired over non-UCSD candidates; benefits are effective as soon as you are employed permanently; as a temp, you can still accrue vacation days and sick days, plus catastrophic health benefits; recommendations from UCSD employers and supervisors are more meaningful than all other references; access to staff education courses, many which are available online, which adds to your credentials vis-a-vis becoming familiar with UCSD policies and procedures
cons: difficulty getting hired for permanent positions; employment and salary advancement subject to State budget constraints; tenured staff (administrative) with outdated skills and outlook which affects morale of younger, more skilled staff and limits opportunities

review_title: Great place to start your IT career (or finish it)
job_title: Programmer Analyst I in La Jolla, CA
pros:
- Lower pressure environment makes it easier to learn and be trained
- IT organizations tend to be flat, so lots of opportunity for involvement in many technical areas
- Get school holidays off and most of winter break (great if you have kids)
- Generous benefits and vacation, time off, and sick leave
- UCSD is heavily decentralized, so your experience will vary from department to department.  But lots of freedom to implement according to your department's needs without needing to comply to a higher organization
- Generally a more casual and laid-back work environment while not descending into mediocrity (varies with departments of course)
- It's a non-profit institution, with an important mission of educating young people
cons:
- Lack of raises or promotions within a department.  It's a government system thing to check against people who want to hook up their buddies with raises.
- Salaries are not comparable to private industry (although when taking benefits into account, perhaps)

review_title: Amazing research institution with impressive research facilities.
job_title: Senior Software Engineering Manager in La Jolla, CA
pros:
While I was employed at UCSD, I saw the impressive research being conducted across multiple disciplines thanks to large grants from NIH and NSF. UC San Diego has departments like the San Diego Supercomputer Center and Scripps Institution of Oceanography that house world class scientists, research faculty and staff. The campus location is gorgeous and there was a spate of new building during the time I was there, including the new Computer Science, Calit2 and Scripps buildings. I had some undergraduate students on my team and they were all bright and motivated. 

Benefits and perks are excellent. Work-life balance was great. People are sharp, talented and very nice.
cons: This is a research university, so some staff is dependent on the soft money available to pay for their salaries. Salaries are not corporate level salaries, but comparable to other academic institutions of its calibre. Some immigration related policies at the University of California were not helpful in the retention of the best researchers and technical staff.

review_title: Available experience for graduate students but demanding
job_title: Teacher Assistant MAE Department in San Diego, CA
pros: There is no shortage of TA or reader positions as long as you seek a position, reach out, email professors, and advocate for yourself. Your adviser may be able to help. It is good experience for graduate students.
cons: Being a Teachers Assistant is demanding on time and sometimes during the quarter it can feel like you really only have a few weeks you can dedicate to your research. For this reason, you want to seek external funding or move from full time to part time. There is a culture of asking more from a TA than what the job description asks but usually it is not too unreasonable. Sometimes, however, it is. Some professors can be unreasonable asking for homework to be graded by the next day, or being rude when having to sign time sheets.  Ask previous TA's , Readers, and other graduate students for advice.

review_title: Low pay, overwork, no light at end of tunnel
job_title: Senior Administrative Analyst in La Jolla, CA
pros: Mostly great colleagues who all care about "making a difference."
cons:
Pay is very low and mandatory deductions for benefits (including retirement benefits and monthly parking) are high, and getting higher each year. There is often NO PLACE to park for staff (if you arrive after 8:45am you will need to park on the other side of the freeway and walk or take a shuttle over). 

There have been no raises in 5yrs for most staff -- not even for cost of living. There are really no opportunities for advancement or recognition. So do NOT accept a low-paying position and think you will wow everyone and be recognized the following year or in years to come. That's unfortunately not how it works around here.

job_title: Programmer Analyst I in La Jolla, CA
pros: The benefits of working at a UC are mostly appreciated by people who are older, have kids and appreciate good retirement plans and insurance. For me, it was also a really supportive environment for me to develop my skills as a team programmer. This was my first job and they were very open to questions and encouraged me to explore the code base.
cons: There was a lot of red tape wrapped around anything interesting. You want to change the link on this site? You've got to find out who owns that site, then convince them it's a reasonable change, only to find out they're not really in charge of the site and you need to talk to someone else, etc. The bureaucracy can be stifling.

review_title: Great atmosphere but too big and bureaucratic for my liking.
job_title: Administrative Assistant III in La Jolla, CA
pros:
Large campus in a beautiful location.
Very solid benefits package, as a temp employee and as a permanent career employee. 
Laid back atmosphere overall.
cons: Large organizations such as UCSD can become bloated with personnel and bogged down with procedures. I work in an administrative support position, and I don't feel as though there is much latitude for being creative  because this type of job is simply all about following established procedures for processing work. Any attempt to deviate from procedure is met with a slap on the wrist for not following the process. Very pedantic, unimaginative work; feeling of being a drone on an assembly line.   Time for me to leave.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in San Diego, CA
pros:
- Pays tuition fees AND a salary, so it's a lot of value at 20 hrs/week.
- Casually professional environment
- Colleagues are very supportive. It is easy to ask somebody to cover for you if you are sick or can't do a section. Of course, you are expected to cover for somebody in return, but it feels good to help somebody out. 
- It's rewarding to see students grow and get better at what they're doing.
cons: - Given the very first point of it covering the tuition fees, it's really hard to focus on the cons. Perhaps it might be sometimes unpleasant to receive negative feedback from certain students, but  it's supposed to happen and you can turn it around and use it to improve your work.

review_title: Academics is a hard knock life
job_title: Program Representative III in La Jolla, CA
pros: The best thing about what I do is that I'm there helping to shape, mold and present the best healthcare the world can offer.  It is a heady thing to be a part of that.   Being a part of medical education can be a very fulfilling path.  Benefits are good, only reason I would recommend.
cons: Academia BS.  Egos get in the way and the good ol boys club is alive and strong.  There isn't a strong team or supportive environment.  Punitive at best.  Faculty are important, but so are many other things that contribute to their success.

review_title: A strong work ethic and smarts will take you far
job_title: Senior Editor in San Diego, CA
pros:
Opportunities to work with brilliant, internationally recognized faculty
Opportunities for growth, across departments or campuses
Mentoring
Great benefits, even for 50% time. Excellent educational benefits, including UC tuition
As a state-funded institution, UC must disclose salaries to public (search the Sacramento Bee)
cons:
I was the only person in my department with a background in publishing. I felt no one in the department really understood what manuscript editors do. It was frustrating when authors reintroduced errors by rejecting my edits, or when they didn't follow good advice.
Job description on paper not entirely accurate; responsibilities not well defined 
Bureaucracy (UC is huge!)
Some faculty can be very demanding and hard to get along with, but if you have a strong work ethic and are smart, they will respect you.
Budget problems; some positions are funded by grants that may or may not be renewed

review_title: Decent place to TA but you have to work to avoid the pettiness that sometimes gets in the way of doing your job
job_title: Teaching Assistant in La Jolla, CA
pros: predictable schedules and on-campus location are great for grad students; SD weather is unbeatable; weekly on-campus farmers market; have some flexibility in what u present in classroom; good training for TAs; good feedback and student surveys help TAs improve
cons: supervisors are hit and miss; some can be so gossipy in team meetings that it's a waste of time to sit through them (but you're paid to be there so there's not much you can do but tolerate it or try to change subjects); high levels of student stress can weigh on TAs who actually care about their pupils

review_title: Great place to work and attend
job_title: Teaching Assistant in La Jolla, CA
pros: Salary (half time) was enough to live on if living in university subsidized housing. Plus health insurance was subsidized, and the position included a tuition waiver. I had a great experience interacting with students and participating in field excursions for the Earth Science program.
cons: The workload was high in at least one large class, and I was assigned there twice. The university did add extra TAs there the next quarter, so it should be more manageable now. And one Professor would make changes and approve the homeworks we wrote. On more than one occasion parts of my section were changed prior to distributing to the class. The changes caused problems with grading metric consistency (which can be a big deal in a class of almost 400). The professor went on to blame the TAs when the issue was brought up saying 'It's your job to deal with that'. Thanks for dumping unnecessary issues on to our already heavy workload.

review_title: Geisel Library is a great opportunity for student jobs
job_title: Student Driver in La Jolla, CA
pros: Loved working with the array of student staff and professional staff.  I worked in the Geisel Library for 2 years and had the opportunity to deliver books to various libraries on the UCSD campus and surrounding satellite campuses.  It was a good experience because of the flexibility with my schedule for classes and it allowed me to make decent money.
cons: Not a lot of cons as this is a general student driver position for the main library on campus but I will say that the vehicles we used did not have functioning AC.  Nothing to complain about really.

job_title: in La Jolla, CA
pros: People you will work with are those who are very aware and careful of the word choices they use when speaking, so you will always feel respected by your co-workers and those in higher positions.  The campus is beautiful and the environment alone and the people you will meet (whether it be students, professors, co workers, etc) will make the job worthwhile.
cons: Some of the cons are as follows: (1) There can be long hours when there are campus events going on.  (2) Students you deal with (if you deal with any) can be very disrespectful at times and frustrating to deal with.  (3) The compensation is not fair/good across the board based on your job title.  Some get better compensation for doing less, which is nonsense.

job_title: Program Coordinator in La Jolla, CA
pros:
The area the campus is in is beautiful
Work/Life Balance
Acknowledgement that diversity and inclusion are values the university believes in and upholds
cons:
Politics - Hierarchy is alive and well - only those at the top have any influence
Outdated mindset in their approach with employees - no flexible work arrangements, raises are very minimal and hard to come by, upward movement is extremely difficult
Operationally runs in an outdated way without considering how to make employees feel more valuable and included in the community
Lack of collaboration across departments

review_title: Find the right niche and it can be a good place.
job_title: Senior Writer in San Diego, CA
pros: Excellent benefits (health and retirement), but they are being degraded as time goes by. Opportunities exist to work with leading reseachers in many different fields on very interesting research.
cons: You have to find the right niche for you. There are a huge number of places, groups, departments on campus that are absolutely crazy and crazy-making. In these places, they treat the staff as if they were disposable and easily replaceable (and given the large number of applicants who are new to UCSD and don't know the "lay of the land" this is somewhat true). But if you can find the right people, where you fit in, it can be very good. You still have to be aware of drawing the line and not working ridiculous hours, even in a good spot.

job_title: House Manager in La Jolla, CA
pros: Flexible schedule to accommodate students, managers understand that you have midterms and things of the sort.  Coworkers are usually pretty cool because they're all in a similar position.
cons:
New employees/managers are always a problem.  New managers tend to clash with older employees who were used to a different management style. New employees either learn from the old employees and have issues with management, or pick up from management and annoy older workers.  
Most of the workers were unhappy with the recent changes during my last year of employment.  The higher ups decided to give us more and more duties every few months and stick us with busy work because they thought our job was too easy.

job_title: Executive Assistant in San Diego, CA
pros: Good place to work. Hard to land permanent position In administrative support without being in temp pool.
cons:
To of drama amongst upper management and what are supposed to be world-renowned researchers. I've witnessed toddler-like tantrums from faculty, and it's apparently deemed acceptable to allow them to verbally abuse staff.

Hillcrest is much more fun culturally.  La Jolla is...strange - don't expect a lot of social niceties there, unless you're at the VA Hospital.

Pay is embarrassingly low for the volume and scope of work expected, however, benefits package is incredibly generous.

review_title: cushy job, no room for movement
job_title: Research Associate III in San Diego, CA
pros: UCSD offers great benefits and a comfortable work environment.  It is a low pressure place to work for the most part, and employees are treated well.  If you like to come to work each day knowing exactly what you are going to do, then the University is the place or you.
cons:
There is a very low ceiling for career advancement if you don't have an advanced degree.  At 30, I had moved about as far as I was going to go unless one of my supervisors decided to retire early.  Many people do the same job for 20 years.  
Also, the HR staff in my department were useless, horrible people who made life very difficult.  Pushing promotions through was nearly impossible thanks to them.

review_title: laid back but political, though great niches exist
job_title: Programmer Analyst IV Supervisor in La Jolla, CA
pros: UCSD is quite laid back in most respects, and generally has flexible and rich work/life balance depending on your group/department and supervisor.  The location is ideal, being close to the beach and freeways; many on-campus locations have great views of the ocean, torrey pines golf course, campus eucalyptus groves, or innovative architecture.
cons: UCSD can sometimes (read "often") be overly political and highly bureaucratic; academic departments act as competing fiefdoms, often competing for head-count, budget, or responsibility.  Many employees tend to be underpaid, and the low pay attracts less motivated/skilled employees; a large percentage of the "lifers" at UCSD fall into this category, since they tend to go into "coast" mode because of the lax rules and low expectations.

review_title: Above average employer overall / average employer among higher education.
job_title: Student Affairs Officer in La Jolla, CA
pros: The caliber of UCSD students makes working with them rewarding and challenging in the good way.  In addition, the benefits of working for the UC are better than average compared to other employers.
cons: The current budget crisis has affected morale across campus.  As state employees, our compensation was never overly generous so the furloughs have been devastating.  Working in Student Affairs at UCSD has been a challenge because of the highly decentralized nature of the campus.

job_title: Graduate Advisor in San Diego, CA
pros: Good work-life balance, understanding management, well-resourced engineering department (in terms of perks, supplies, etc.), close to the beach
cons: Managers who need more training on delegating, being assertive, advocating for their staff (especially the little things because the big things they pretty much have down really well). Leadership and management being more intentional and committed to diversity, equity, and inclusion (not just saying those words when there's incidents across the country) such as creating a committee of staff, faculty, and students. Currently none of those exist in my department.

review_title: IT Professionals - Run and don't look back
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Diego, CA
pros: Benefits and it's in San Diego
cons: IT jobs underpaid, no raises EVER, almost no promotions

review_title: Awesome place to work overshadowed by politics and low pay.
job_title: Programmer Analyst III in La Jolla, CA
pros:
Pension plan if you work for more than 5 years
Great Medical insurance package 
Laid back atmosphere
Convenient location
Many interesting people
cons:
Pay is a joke and no raises in sight.
Employees have to pay $95/mo for parking, but parking spots are not guaranteed. You have to look for spots just like students do.
Faculty is the king. They report to no one do whatever they want and treat people like garbage. School administration does not care.
No promotions. You have to apply and interview for every position.
No money for hardware upgrades, most of the equipment is outdated.

review_title: Great Ideals but Little Follow Through
job_title: Engineer/Consultant in San Diego, CA
pros: Sailing on research vessels is a dream come true for anyone with a wayfaring heart and strong work ethic. The company pays well for entry level positions in this regard, "when you are at sea."
cons: Most of the support staff is non-existent due in large part to the organizations lack of military oversight. There are pockets of great people but the whole functions like an angry version of Jersey Shores. Beyond that, if you are unfortunate enough to be stuck in port the pay drops to minimum wage or close to it.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in La Jolla, CA
pros: If you stay there long enough, you enjoy seniority and good compensation for not doing much. Depending on the office, unit, or department, the work is pretty much chill and you can go on autopilot. Not sure if this is a pro or a con. I know I needed more of a challenge. Very good non-salary compensation, great health and other benefits.
cons: People are unfairly promoted and there are lots of people being paid tons of money for pushing paper. Most of the work are done by workers below them, while they reap the credit. Many unhappy employees who are there to collect the free government handout and they don't get rid of the incompetent employees. There are always "restructuring" initiatives aimed at making the place better, but no real good solutions have been instituted to make this place better.

job_title: Administrative Assistant II in La Jolla, CA
pros: Great benefits.  If you are lucky, you end up in a work group with at least some people you can stand.  Sometimes, I've heard, the benefits are the only reason people stay here.  It may be a highly-rated university, but the admin staff are not treated well.  Without our recently-negotiated CUE union we would never have gotten a raise.
cons: Poor management.  The fish stinks from the head down.  I have what I consider a good supervisor, relatively speaking, but he allowed a sick person to remain in our department, who ended up bullying me and then tried to get me fired.  They did not succeed, but still,  he knew she was a liar and rumor spreader, and did nothing about it.

job_title: Administrator in La Jolla, CA
pros:
Wonderful staff- hard working and dedicated. Great training and support from the Human Resources Department. I've been promoted twice. Stimulating environment in a beautiful setting.
Great benefits.
cons: The money could be better. Worst thing right now is the Chancellor and his office. He's just a nasty insecure guy who all of us are hoping will leave soon. Has brought in his own leadership team and the whole group is "less than talented." In my former position, I had to deal with his Chief of Staff-she's just as unstable and mean spirited as the Chancellor.

job_title: Administrative Assistant III in La Jolla, CA
pros: Where I had worked, they were open to professional growth but only in terms of a preference to hire within.  This was both a good and bad thing.  Can't beat the view though.  My employment was also fairly good about work/life balance.  It wasn't frowned upon to leave right at 5.  Where I had worked, they were also open to new ideas and technology.  So, that was great.
cons: Pay definitely could have been better.  It's a large organization.  So, there are going to be organizational/bureaucratic issues.  Professional development should be encouraged.

review_title: Great place to start out if your a student at UCSD
job_title: Circulation Assistant in La Jolla, CA
pros: Pros: Good student employment opportunities. Fair compensation for students. Great balance between work and school. I found most of my co-workers to be great individuals to work with and enjoyed the time I spent working there. It's a beautiful campus and on campus restaurants can be reached relatively quickly from the library.
cons: Cons: Required to work normal hours during finals week. Had to work late hours in order to help close the library. It's a library so it tends to get very busy and hectic during midterms/finals week. The circulation desk has a tendency to get overrun by overstressed students so that isn't always fun.

review_title: Working for EH&S provided me with a new career path.
job_title: Senior Environment Health and Safety Technician in La Jolla, CA
pros: UCSD functions as a small city, and has to comply with  a slew of regulatory agencies to maintain all their hazardous materials permits in compliance. They provide you with so much training that will really help in building your resume. Most jobs within EH&S are half in-office and half in the field, so there is a great deal of flexibility in your schedule which I always loved.
cons: Having an opportunity to be promoted will take a long time (5 years with no promotion in my case). It is difficult if not impossible to be "promoted" but positions do open up that will allow you to reach for higher pay by applying for a higher level position when there are vacancies.

job_title: Caterer in San Diego, CA
pros: Nice People, Easy Job. I liked working there since the pay was good. The managers there are very considerate and your coworkers are always there to help you
cons: As a newcomer they make you work really undesirable shift. For example as a student, I had to work some shifts that started at 6:00AM while having a full schedule of classes right after gwtting off of work

job_title: Postdoctoral Scholar in San Diego, CA
pros: As a scientist, UCSD has wonderful resources to carry out a variety of scientific research. UCSD has many labs at the forefront of my research area as well as many others. The location of UCSD is terrific as well, with beautiful coastal living or more urban living, some of which can be affordable.
cons: Academia in general is a challenging endeavor. Though this environment has all the trappings of a terrific job, it is still at the whims of general academia and is not immune to the national troubles in funding scientific research.

review_title: Great research but not great as an institution overall
job_title: Lab Assistant in La Jolla, CA
pros: There is amazing research being done at this university and I worked alongside truly brilliant professionals while I was here.
cons: Admin/HR/services can be a nightmare. I was locked out of all my accounts for a week because IT thought I had quit when I had given no indication of doing so.  When I finally did quit, HR never filed my paperwork and was very unresponsive when I tried contacting them after they were still emailing me about payroll after I left. There is also not nearly enough staff parking although that may have improved since I left.

review_title: I mean, I was a graduate student...
job_title: Graduate Student Researcher & Teaching Assistant in La Jolla, CA
pros:
(Just FYI - mainly filling this out for Glassdoor access)
Great advisor. Physics department has great people in it. Most people are collaborative, in my experience. Beautiful campus. Sustainability resource center has some great people in it. Lots of interesting research. Farmer's market on Tuesdays is always nice. Generally most of the students are friendly folks; it's a nice place to be around.
cons: Have had a couple instances of testy relations between a supervising professor and one or more of the teaching assistants. Graduate student stipends (not department specific) are not enough - most graduate students are rent burdened (Union study showed average of ~ 42% of grad income is to pay for housing). UC administration can be antagonistic towards labor movements.

review_title: Great place to work if you don't have a lot of career motivation and want to lay back and collect a paycheck.
job_title: Senior Administrative Analyst in La Jolla, CA
pros: Beautiful location. Good work-life balance. Pension plan. Vacation benefits.
cons: Depending on which department you work in, you may or may not have a competent boss. Most upper management are academics and long-time administrators and they are making decisions outside of their specialized field. Very siloed and insular. Departments and campuses do not share resources or work well together. It's very much a "my tiny area first" environment. Hard to fire anyone, so motivation to do great work is limited.

review_title: Great place to work, but depends on field of study
job_title: Teaching Assistant in La Jolla, CA
pros: Great city, relaxed atmosphere, sophisticated professors.  When working with a professor, most that I have worked with are eager to talk and discuss their research topic.  If you have anything in common with them, then they are pleased to hear your advice/thoughts.
cons: Compared to other UC's or other universities, UCSD still lacks the national recognition then the likes of UCLA or UC Berkeley.  If you graduate, the best bet is to make connections with the professor to seek a job.  If you field is outside of medicine or engineering, then the place may not be for you, as the focus is heavily medical and engineer based.

job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in La Jolla, CA
pros: Grad office staff is great, career advising is great (at least while you're still a student). If your advisor is able to fund you as a GSR, you'll live comfortably enough.  Food's available on campus, and parking's free on weekends (for now).
cons: Allocation of resources (like office space) varies heavily from department to department. In ours, you had to know which offices were available and ask for them, because the department wasn't keeping track well enough to hand them out.

review_title: Your experience will vary entirely based on which dept you work for.
job_title: Social Worker in San Diego, CA
pros: Once I found the right program, I was glad to work for UCSD.  The benefits are excellent, the salary not so much.  If I'd been able to work on campus it would have been great.
cons:
I started in the Med Center as a social worker and it was terrible.  There is no support for social workers in the hospital.  
If you work off campus you miss out on a lot of the benefits of working for UCSD,

job_title: UCDC Peer Advisor in La Jolla, CA
pros: I really enjoyed my time working here as a UCDC Peer Advisor. All the advisor in the office was always eager to help and genuinely cared for their students. In my opinion, AIP is totally underrated by the student body here. With advisors going the extra mile to make sure you secure that internship (which ultimately helps your resume stand out), I don't understand why turnout is so small.
cons: Since UCSD is such a huge campus, it's pretty difficult to spread the word to students. Flyering, info sessions, and classroom advertising can only do so much. Sometimes students can seem nonchalant and disaffected, but with some determination, you'll find students to reach out to.

job_title: Programmer Analyst III in La Jolla, CA
pros:
I had great bosses; they want to do cutting-edge research and the important thing is to figure out creative ways of getting the work done. I worked in a science lab and they were not very political or "stylish", just work with colleagues to do interesting things.

The University still has a pension plan and great medical plans.
cons: As always, you pay for the pension and medical care with below market rate salaries. They try to keep up, but you have to count the benefits to get a real idea of the environment.

job_title: Assistant Project Scientist in La Jolla, CA
pros:
UCSD is a great place to work, at least in my department. Project scientists have to hustle for grants because our salary is not supported by the university at all, but I have found that the department is pretty collaborative and there seems to be plenty of funding, if you are willing to ask around and get involved on different projects.

The administrative support at UCSD is pretty good. Contracts and grants officers help with the timely submission of grant proposals and there are career development resources on campus.
cons: The downsides are more the downsides of being a soft-money researcher in general, i.e., it can feel unstable because your future is dependent on obtaining grant funding, which is very competitive.

job_title: Researcher in La Jolla, CA
pros: Weather is perfect all year around.  The facilities are great.  Being a walking distance away from the ocean is wonderful.  Basically, if you want to be on a constant vacation, San Diego is the place to live and UCSD is the place to work.
cons:
Cost of living is unbearable.  La Jolla is a very expensive neighbourhood and many people end up having to live a long distance away from the university.  The university is trying to expand very fast creating major problems with parking. 
Many of the people do not belong there.  Those who are are being taken advantage of by those who are not.

review_title: Working in History and Humanities at UC San Diego
job_title: Teacher Assistant in La Jolla, CA
pros: Both departments are superior in regard to their faculty involvement with their students and made working in the departments a great learning and didactic experience. fault of the administration of the departments however, but to the University of California's own intransigence reg
cons: Unit recently the salary level was low and remained so most of my tenure of 8 years. This was not  due to any fault of the departments themselves, but to the system wide inadequacy of pay structure for teacher assistants. Fortunately, a new salary has now been negotiated by the union with the UC and this situation should change.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Diego, CA
pros: UCSD is amazing insofar as there are amazing opportunities to learn, whether via a speaker or through a workshop. Professional development is prized. There is a very diverse student body socio-economically, and in many other ways as well, and diversity is touted as an overt value. Amazing benefits.
cons: Low salaries-- regardless of your level of experience, HR will low-ball you if you are coming in as staff. There's very little room for growth in the way of professional advancement unless you move jobs, and very few pay increases are available.

job_title: Senior Analyst/Supervisor in San Diego, CA
pros: An institution of higher learning that lives its mission by sending employees to continue learning.  Also, they value you as a human and understand you are passionate about your career, but that there are other aspects of life that are important to make you a well-rounded person and contributing member of the team.  They truly do want to keep you for your whole career!
cons: San Diego lacks infrastructure, and therefore everyone who works at UC San Diego suffers a terrible commute - no matter if you're willing to bike, take public transit, or pay $90/mo to park.  You will suffer en route to work.

review_title: UCSD is a good place for postdocs, depending on the lab
job_title: Postdoctoral Fellow in San Diego, CA
pros:
UCSD is one of the top-rated research institutions in the country. 
Since UC San Diego is located within a city known for biotech there are a lot of career development resources and opportunities to network. 
For the most part (from the people I know in life sciences) postdocs are paid by the mandated amount stipulated by the NIH.
cons: As with any school, the success and happiness of your postdoc does depend on a fair bit of luck and which lab you end up in. The school itself recognizes postdoctoral fellows to the same extent that most other schools do (which can be a positive or a negative, depending on your perspective).

review_title: Three years, great reviews, no raise??
job_title: Staff Research Associate II in La Jolla, CA
pros:
Fantastic research, and amazing brains on that research
Lots of money coming in due to UCSD's place in research world
Lots of conveniences on campus:  tons of food, coffee, post office, etc...
Job stability - because it's almost impossible to get fired.
cons:
I have to pay $80 a month for parking?
Awful, awful chance for promotions and raises: breeding of apathy due to this
Huge bureaucracy, along with apathetic workers = everything take forever
Too many below average workers still getting paid because getting fired is extremely difficult

job_title: Principal Analyst in San Diego, CA
pros: Campus resources - access to library, gym, etc.
cons: Low salaries and no upward mobility for staff create an organization with high turnover. Many employees do very little work in a 40 hour week. This is the norm. Upper administrators have little if any managerial experience and are far more concerned with perceptions of themselves than with what is in the best interest of the organization or even basic quality of work. If you want a place to sit around surfing the internet, this is for you. If you want to be productive, complete projects that have an influence, or even just do basic quality work for the day, run far and run fast from UCSD. Especially avoid central administration.

job_title: Bioengineering PhD Student in La Jolla, CA
pros: Geography is excellent, i.e. great weather, outdoor activities, and there is ample opportunity for individuals in the biotechnology field. There is also a supportive environment for startups to get off the ground, though there haven't been many blockbuster startups coming from the area yet.
cons: The city is a bit lackluster; it does not offer what a San Francisco or a New York would be able to offer in terms of citylife. UCSD is primarily located in the suburbs. The Bioengineering department, while possessing excellent research credentials, falls short in supporting and rewarding excellent teaching from its faculty.

review_title: Great location, great faculty, great scientific community
job_title: PhD Student in La Jolla, CA
pros:
Great research community (Scripps, Burnham, and Salk Institutes all nearby)
Many job opportunities in surrounding area
Great reputation in physical sciences
Beautiful location (views of pacific ocean from some points)
cons:
Terrible parking situation (~$81/month; more cars than spaces available; $60 fines; essentially no choice but to use public transportation if living off campus)

Disorganized infrastructure (campus maps are complicated and unclear; building names and markers are hard to find)

review_title: Great Place.... If you can tolerate the University environment
job_title: in La Jolla, CA
pros: Overall a very friendly environment (and I personally enjoyed my job functions a lot).  Very flexible, beautiful campus to get to work on, and San Diego is a great place.
cons: Biggest is that it's a University environment - be prepared to deal with bureaucracy, incompetent bosses, lazy co-workers, and rules and red tape up the yin-yang.  Assuming you can cope with that - go for it!

job_title: Medical Assistant/Surgery Tech in San Diego, CA
pros: I enjoyed working for ucsd medical center for 22yrs , i enjoyed working with my co-worker and the care and relationship with my patients. Teaching and learning that i recieved and that i was able to retire, and take along with me to another job
cons: knowing  that i was leaving my departments employees short handed, know how we had to work hard to keep our department together to give our patient the best care no matter what.

job_title: Statistician in San Diego, CA
pros: University of California San Diego has been a good school to work for.  They were available with many opportunities coming directly out school.  The benefits packages are pretty good to for full-time employees.
cons: The institutionalized nature of their HR department has been a headache to go through.  Probably a joint problem of large "company" and being technically a government institution.  Too much red tape.

job_title: Senior Research Associate IV in San Diego, CA
pros: Benefits are great - medical, dental, flex funds, pension, etc. Lots of job stability after the initial 6 month probationary period. Many unions depending on job position, and automatic annual cost of living raises. Many staff events
cons: Lots of bureaucracy which makes it difficult to get promotions or hire new staff. Difficult to speak to anyone in HR or find the person you need to speak to. Pension plan is really expensive out of pocket.

job_title: Postdoctoral Fellow in La Jolla, CA
pros:
The whether is great, love the city.
The university offers a very open environment for collaboration between labs, departments and institutes around the area.
cons:
It's hard to live on the stipend as a scientist or a postdoc from UCSD, some labs pay less than NIH scale, but the area is very expensive... 
Generally speaking, most people have to do a 5-year postdoc or even two postdocs to be promoted to a project scientist (if you get your transitional grant). Postdocs are generally under-appreciated in this school. Not enough help or training is provided to the trainees in terms of career development. The postdoctoral association has started to include some special events for the postdocs to be familiar to environment other than academia, which is very much needed. 
PIs, however, at least the ones that I have interacted with, do not care or support your career development.

job_title: Programmer Analyst IV Supervisor in San Diego, CA
pros: For the most part, the stability of your job along with a relatively low pressure environment is nice at the time. Being at a university is, if not anything else, intellectually stimulating. The flexibility was nice as well.
cons: After putting in over 14 years at UC San Diego, my project was no longer funded and all the connections I had made in my time there turned away from me. Years and years of salary freezes, helping people for no benefit, working for the greater good all for naught. NEVER depend on this organization looking out for your career goals if you are non-faculty. It is not in their best interest.

job_title: Conversation Leader in La Jolla, CA
pros: Most of the teachers that conversation leaders work with are very friendly and most of the students are enthusiastic to learn English. It is a fun, international oriented environment to work in that is also convenient to UCSD's main campus. One can work a lot of hours during the summer.
cons: The pay is low and sometimes it is hard to get the hours that one needs during the school year. Sometimes the work gets repetitive if teachers only want you to ask the students discussion questions, rather than using you for other duties.

job_title: Lab Assistant in La Jolla, CA
pros:
Scheduling was very flexible, as a student worker.
Access to interesting and world renowned faculty
Great lab experience and the views of the Pacific Ocean can't be beat.
cons:
Parking is never free unless you work early in the morning or in the evening and thus get access to the limited street parking. 

As a student worker, no real downside with SIO.

job_title: Information Systems Analyst in La Jolla, CA
pros:
You are exposed to many forms of hardware and software.  It's up to you how much you want to learn.
Working on Campus is great.
Time off and Holidays are fair.  MLK, Cesar Chavez, Christmas vacation, etc.
cons:
Work can be stagnant.  Funding determines everything. 
It would take a miracle to get a raise, much alone a competitive salary.  Management pay themselves bonuses, but the staff do not get any.
Pay is abysmal..I'll say it again, ABYSMAL.  On average, you will make 20% less working here.

review_title: Worked in Housing and Dining Department as a student and lead supervisor for three years.
job_title: Student Lead in San Diego, CA
pros: Pay is great for a food service job for a student on campus, meal perks are generous for every shift worked, ability to quickly be promoted to lead and then student manager if someone chooses to work enough to gain those titles.
cons: High turnover rate sometimes leads to stressful and understaffed shifts, especially for the dining halls on campus. New coworkers will generally be VERY inexperienced, as this was often a first job for students.

job_title: Administrative Specialist in San Diego, CA
pros:
- Job stability
- Good health, vision, dental and retirement benefits
- Job security
- Unique work environment if you're interested in the research and medical field
- Great place to make career connections
cons:
- SLOW opportunities for grow
- Salary cap on moves within the university system
- Very low pay under industry standards, no opportunity for raises unless you move departments, management has no flexibility to offer compensation incentives to stay. 
- Employees have to pay for their own parking spots $80/mo (and fight the students for space)
- No opportunities for growth within departments
- High rate of turnover in administrative roles
- Many employees that stay out of convenience
- Extremely difficult to remove low-performers from job roles

job_title: Administrative Assistant III in La Jolla, CA
pros: relaxed atmosphere, beautiful weather, students are great, some really cool people, encouraging of professional development
cons: hard to get promoted or switch careers to a different path; parking is expensive and hard to find; union dues expensive; after all the deductions are taken out of paycheck you earn very little; people who should be fired just get recycled to other departments because firing someone is impossible and then it's up to the rest of us to figure out what to do with these incompetent, lazy, and awful people; campus food is gross and expensive

review_title: Great Place to work - salaries could be more.
job_title: in San Diego, CA
pros: Great benefits - start with 3 weeks vacation, 8 days of sick time - which you can accumulate up to 500 hours. Vacation time rolls over as well. Family health insurance options... we have quite a few. Many opportunities to move around between campus and health and within each. Once you are an employee, it's easier to move around.
cons: work life balance could be better, salary could be better.

review_title: This job made me an ardent reader while helping me pay for college.
job_title: Interlibrary Loan Assistant in San Diego, CA
pros:
Get to interact with people of various backgrounds, education. 
Friendly staff, and overall very relaxed environment.
Great library benefits, borrow books internationally for free, the perks are very nice if you like to read. It made me an avid reader after working here.
cons:
Dealing with old books means you are constantly battling with dust and who knows what.
During school finals week or the beginning when the students are enthusiastic about learning, work load increases dramatically.

job_title: Student Worker in San Diego, CA
pros: Working at Geisel as a student worker is a very flexible job. It is one of the higher paying student jobs on campus.
cons: The job does get repetitive and is a very mindless chores. It's on campus so if you are a student you may not appreciate the feeling of always being on campus.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Diego, CA
pros: UC San Diego is a huge academic setting with many research laboratories. You will have the opportunity to interact with many PIs, graduate students, and postdoc flows, also scientists.
cons: UC San Diego has been criticized greatly by its lack of efficiency on the administrative level. I totally agree with it. There are many many administrative branches and most of them do not talk to each other and do not know to solve a simple task.

job_title: PhD Graduate Student in San Diego, CA
pros: Being a graduate student is challenging, but it does offer a steady, if small, income source.  UC San Diego offers fair health care and graduate housing for a couple of years which can help offset to cost of high rents in San Diego proper.
cons: PhDs can take many years (mine took 7).  The low salary meant that I barely saved any money during this time especially given the rent that I paid once my graduate housing time was over.  UC San Diego offers many career coaching opportunities, however it is still quite a grim market for PhDs especially in the Academy.

review_title: Great place to postdoc in computational chemistry
job_title: Postdoctoral Fellow in San Diego, CA
pros: This institution has a significant number of renowned computational chemistry and biological physics professors here. You will make many valuable connections here
cons: There are fewer renowned experimental biophysics professors and few groups doing academic drug discovery projects, so there are some, but not a large number, of experimentalists to collaborate with

job_title: in San Diego, CA
pros: One of the best UC schools with heavy emphasis on scientific research and development. The city itself is a "heaven" to me with great weather, scenery, people.......
cons: The reputation of the university is not as high as those Ivy Leagues in the US northeast region even though the quality of the research is great, the university should do more to promote itself.

job_title: Lecturer in La Jolla, CA
pros: Students are bright, colleagues are great, administrative staff is very competent.
cons: This would be a great job if it were full time. Unfortunately UCSD seems to operate a bit like Wal-Mart in that the administrative staff seems to go out of their way to make sure that you're only ever part time. The effect of this practice (1) turns what would be a decent annual starting salary ($49K) into a poor salary ($22K), and (2) makes it hard to become benefits-eligible.

job_title: Graduate Student in San Diego, CA
pros: You get to work with some of the best and brightest minds in academia and there are plenty of events, both social and academic, to keep you occupied. The location doesn't hurt either
cons: Pay for graduate students is low, as is typical of any graduate school. Administration can be slow or uncommunicative, so if you want something, you really have to push for it. You also don't have any guaranteed vacation beyond university holidays

job_title: Executive Assistant in La Jolla, CA
pros: Excellent benefits package, working with like-minded people who have the same mission of doing their part to advance UC, opportunity to move around, retirement plan.
cons: Salary lower than in other industries, large bureaucracy where nothing happens fast, many items get bottle - necked.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in La Jolla, CA
pros:
1. Access to the Medical Education Deans for consultation/direction.  
2. Non-management staff who have been with the Division for more than 2 years are amazingly supportive and attempt to neutralize the daily pressures.
3. Working with the Medical Students was truly an honor & a privilege.  I feel comforted knowing the future of healthcare policy & practices will be managed by Doctors like those trained at UCSD School of Medicine.
cons:
1.  Intense work environment (this can be good or bad!).  Almost every decision feels like it is "life or death " which may be the nature of dealing with Medical Doctors.  

2. At UCSD, beyond having the administrator role, the Educational Deans are also faculty & researchers, so their time is very important.  Everyone gets that.  However, at times, it felt as if the issue I was presenting was not being fully heard b/c the Dean may have been "distracted" or as if the issue was so trivial, s/he seemed irritated by the inquiry.  

3. In short, the support staff (non-faculty) who are critical to supporting the medical student experience by providing academic support such as schedule coordination; quarterly enrollment of students; reserving rooms with appropriate learning tools, etc.; creating/facilitating student wellness events including providing admin support  (e.g. catering contracts); administration of financial support for student organizations' events; and managing prep & execution of diversity outreach & developing/sustaining community partnerships and large scale events (e.g. commencement & student orientations); were treated as disposable/easily replaceable with a temp. worker.  Not a moral booster esp. when one is rarely sincerely acknowledged and thanked for their efforts. Not all people need this; however, as a new employee, it is incredibly helpful to know when you've gone above & beyond that, your supervisor & work directors understand what was needed and appreciate the effort of the team of staff (ex. working on weekends, after-hours, and doing the work of two positions because the unit is understaffed).

To clarify, the difference between the newly hired staff & the "veteran" staff was that the latter was better-compensated so they could better afford the long-term therapy needed to survive the daily stress at the UCSD School of Medicine Medical Education Division.

review_title: Great Place to Work if You're in the Right Dept
job_title: in San Diego, CA
pros: UCSD is truly a world-class educational institution with a well-respected reputation. I took great pride in both being a part of this phenomenal university and working with some of the most brilliant minds in the field of medical research. Up until the last couple of years, I was happy beyond description. I knew people in other depts who were just as happy, others, not so much.  Each dept has its own set of pluses and minuses. I felt fortunate to have found a good dept for as long as I did.
cons: Politics, politics, politics. Your paycheck may not have a government name on it but it might as well, because everything that happens at UCSD, every decision made, every plan put into action is politically motivated. Pay: if you get in at mid-management level you'll be okay. Anything below that, forget it, you'll be stuck paywise your whole career at UCSD unless your job requires you join a union. Even then, they will suck a pretty penny off your paycheck so even a union job won't take you far. If you get a job at a director level or higher, you will be sailing a smooth ocean. Directors and higher are compensated quite nicely as are tenured faculty. A lot of faculty and upper level management make astounding salaries and you have to ask yourself -- are they really worth it? (The Nobel Prize winners, yes, but the others?) Unfortunately it is the students who bear the brunt of the high salaries. Every time you turn around they are raising students fees. The majority of the kids do not come from wealthy families, but ones that respect and encourage higher education. Ultimately the kids and their families are socked with higher student loans that will take a decade or more to pay back. It's not right.

review_title: Secure and Fun but sometimes trite
job_title: Fund Manager Assistant in La Jolla, CA
pros:
One of the top Universities in the world.
Something new is being developed every day.
Great working environment.
Beach is right down the road.
Great weather.
cons:
No parking.
Food is expensive.
The work that we get is usually repetitive and for the most part on simple side. I prefer a challenging environment when it comes to working, but I'm not complaining about having this job in this economy.

job_title: in La Jolla Shores, CA
pros: It was great being a student here, the professors research was top notch. The lecturers were always a great time, and the projects we can complete on campus never limited us
cons: No night life. If you are looking for someplace to have a good time you do not want to come here. It also is a huge campus with lots of places to get lost in.

job_title: Cashier in San Diego, CA
pros: I dont  work weekends, we close at 5pm,  when it is not busy we can use the internet to do homework or go on Facebook
cons: Customers complain a lot, when we are busy it can be nonstop for 10 hours ,  you are responsible for a having complete knowledge of the massive parking area that UCSD controls and of all the permit availability

review_title: An expensive place to work with poor pay
job_title: Editor in La Jolla, CA
pros: The location is beautiful if that is important to you, and a lot of really intelligent, really interesting people work at UCSD. Three week of vacation almost immediately is really nice, and the health benefits would be extremely affordable ($20/month for Kaiser for a family of four) if other expenses, such as parking, didn't eat up the cost savings.
cons:
$80 a month for a parking pass that doesn't guarantee a place to park, especially if you get to work after 8:00 a.m.  UCSD police are fanatically about giving expensive tickets that double in cost if you don't pay right away, so don't even think about parking in a Faculty spot if you only have a Staff permit.  On top of parking fees, many staff positions are union positions, which means $48 in union fees are deducted each month regardless of whether or not you join the union.  Considering that the last union-negotiated raise that I received in 2011 amounted to $.73 a month (that's not a typo, I received less than one dollar a month as my last raise), it hardly seems worth the investment. These fees go up every year, as do the health care costs, but raises are often frozen for years at a time, so it's possible to make LESS money each year that you stay at UCSD.  As in corporate America, Department heads and management teams who make the fiscal decisions see employees only as numbers, and will immediately suggest furloughs and lay offs for the worker bees whenever there are budget cuts (which seems like every year), then collect bonuses that equal more than your average worker's annual salary for making those "tough decisions."

In general, pay is not good at UCSD.  The only people paid well are the people at the top of the pyramid, and for many of us, that measly paycheck only comes once a month. I think that's what I hate most about UCSD is that once-a-month paycheck.

review_title: Hard Work but to be expected as graduate student
job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in La Jolla, CA
pros:
Large campus, many resources
Many research opportunities
Professors try their best to help students be successful in their projects
Health care system is excellent for graduate student insurance
cons: Can have unnecessary politics in office situations including pleasing professors over needs of students.  You can get lost in the system due to the large school size, standing out is important.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in La Jolla, CA
pros:
Top research institute and good working attitude. Very good weather! People could have good work life balance if they could manage to do it. 
You can have a lot of fun in San Diego.
cons:
Bureaucracy makes things very slow. Graduate student offices respond to things ineffectively. 
Living near campus is extremely expensive.  And it takes on average more than five years to graduate.

job_title: Anonymous in La Jolla, CA
pros: It's good to have it. And that's probably all the pros.
cons:
My comments on the N/A loop

1. They asked all the passengers to get off and wait for another without a reason. It took extra 15mins of waiting. I have experienced that for three times. It's really frustrating.

2. For some reasons, some buses parked by a bus stop and are "out of service". We needed to wait for more than 30mins before the next bus come. And that is during the hours of normal service (9:40am)

I think they don't care about shuttle service for staffs or employees at all.

job_title: Student Manager in La Jolla, CA
pros:
*Flexible with work schedules
*Free meal for every shift worked
*Gives plenty of opportunities to move up 
*Great first job that sharpens ones cleaning and cooking skills
cons:
*Constantly understaffed
*Bloated salaries for most workers and students pay extreme prices to maintain this
*Very slow to get things changed/fixed

review_title: Life of chemistry graduate students at UCSD
job_title: Graduate Student in La Jolla, CA
pros:
In the inorganic track, it is a small but relatively close community. People are happy to share instruments or lend chemicals to other labs. 
All the groups here have cool chemistry, e.g. magnetism, MOFs, carbenes, silica and electrochemistry.
cons:
The housing is so expensive. The school is turning the cheap grad housing into undergrad housing and offering more expensive new housing to grad students. 
And the parking permit is expensive as well. Always not enough parking spots.
