job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in La Jolla, CA
pros: As a graduate student at UCSD, you will be able to make new discoveries that push science in new directions, while developing your own talents and learning new skills to make you an effective scientist, whether your goal is a position in industry or academia. Collaboration is encouraged and even rewarded (there is a yearly competition for graduate students to pitch collaborative research projects). Pay and benefits vary department to department, but most, if not all, STEM fields will pay your tuition / fees and provide a stipend. The campus has a lot of activities and things going on that students can get involved in.
cons: Suffice it to say, my advisor was so much like Prof Smith from PhD Comics that the webcomic is almost too hard to read. I'm not saying every advisor will be like that, but every faculty member has their challenges. Each will have their own approach to working hours, vacation days, sick days, etc. Some faculty may ask you to be in lab from 7am to 5pm Monday through Friday plus 3 Saturdays a month, and some may not even remember who you are and that you work for them. There is no consistency between faculty in terms of seeing students to graduation. My advice is to seek out former students and ask them how their experience was, how well their expectations for graduation were met, and how well their advisor prepared them for, or even helped to make the next step in their career.

review_title: Don't work for the CSO Program
job_title: Community Service Officer in La Jolla, CA
pros: Hours are in one go and it is flexible with your schedule.  Some of the shifts that involve sitting in Geisel or other places allow you to study on the job.
cons: Coworkers were rude and always riding people to work faster on the job.  Forced to ride bikes on campus so the job requires lots of physical stamina on escort shifts.  Make up fake reasons to fire student employees by claiming fake trainings that were actually done but the record was lost to fire employees.  Supervisor had favoritism and was a rude and unpleasant person with a Napoleon complex.

job_title: Postdoctoral Scholar in San Diego, CA
pros: Generally good facilities. Lots of research places around which is good for collaborations & access to different types of equipment.
cons: There are so many postdocs here really spread out that it is hard to a cohesive group. Since so many people want to come here there is not much emphasis on trying to keep/promote good staff.

job_title: Laboratory Assistant II in San Diego, CA
pros: I think since UCSD is such a large campus and there are so many different lab environments, each review can vary greatly. I was fortunate to have a situation where I had great co-workers even though my PI lives in Europe. It was an enjoyable work environment, which was very relaxed while still being very engaging and interesting. I think the benefits are pretty standard for this type of job. I have learned many techniques in this lab, which I think are extremely valuable to my resume as a research technician going foward, which can be attributed to the willingness of the post-docs in this lab to teach.
cons:
As far as salary goes, it is difficult for me to judge, since I am officially classified as a "Lab Asst 2" although I am very overqualified for the job description. I am the lab manager, and provide the only research tech support for the entire lab as well as managing the animal colony which in the past has been the sole responsibility of another full time animal technician. I would say I am qualified to be classified as either a SRA 1 or SRA 2 (Staff Research Associate) for which I would be paid 5-6k more. However, I do believe the compensation for someone for the qualifications of a Lab Asst 2 is appropriate, as it only requires 1-2 years of experience and is probably targeted for someone who has recently graduated.
 
The main issue I have had on campus has been parking, the only time you can find parking easily is if you have a red A pass, which is only issued to professors and certain post-docs. Having a green B staff parking pass costs $80/month, which decreases your salary as well. Depending on the time you arrive on campus, even with a green B staff pass, it can be next to impossible to find parking, especially when school starts in the fall.

I have run into some issues in the past with some people in various committees such as the Animal Care Program and Safety Officers. I imagine that these people have been in their positions for a long time and seem to be either very rude and impatient, even to people dealing with them for the first time, or extremely resistant to changes that would help make their jobs more efficient and effective.

Finally, there doesn't seem to be very much room for career growth/improvement in the research lab environment. When you are a technician or lab manager the position seems to be one that is held for a year or two while the employee is figuring out their next step, and it is difficult to imagine a long term career plan in academia without going on to get a graduate degree, which can be a 5-7 year commitment while you will be unable to work and are given a paltry stipend.

job_title: Senior Development Engineer in La Jolla, CA
pros: Taking leaves for vacation or medical reason is usually not a problem. Work-life balance is good. Benefits seem good, but they can very vague on the details on when you can retire.
cons: The current mindset of UCSD is that all staff is completely replaceable with little to no effort. They will do anything to keep faculty but do little to keep staff that have been there for years. Salary for staff is below industry by great length. High turn over for the normal rank and file staff member.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Diego, CA
pros: Great research school that can benefit a lot of people coming from a huge variety of different cultures and backgrounds while also serving as a great place to earn a distinguishable degree.
cons: The campus is very big leading to a lot of walking. This would mean that if you are not a fan of exercising your lower half of your body, you could end up having leg pains.

review_title: A good place for postdoc research
job_title: Postdoctoral Associate in La Jolla, CA
pros: Very research-oriented environment. You have access to great intellectual resources in the neighboring institutes, like Salk, Scripps and San-Ford Burnham. UCSD is located in the bio-hub, where you can find a lot of big pharmas, small startups and midsized companies. This is kinda nice to make you think alternative careers.
cons: Because the mandated promotion, some PI will force postdoc to stop working after 5 years to be in compliance with UC postdoc union policy

job_title: Student Worker in La Jolla, CA
pros:
* Super easy hiring process. Everyone gets a job
* Flexible scheduling around classes and extra-curricular
* Great pay for an easy job ($9.23) + $8 to spend on food every shift you work
* Friendly management and co-workers
cons:
Really have none...I guess it depends on which market you're working at. I've heard some markets have really terrible management and are mean/rude for no reason. 

I guess the biggest thing is a lot of the people working there have never had a job before. So they sometimes lack common and sense and initiative.

job_title: Tutor in La Jolla, CA
pros: This is a great opportunity for students to broaden their understanding of material by tutoring other freshman and sophomore students in the Electrical Engineering major
cons: Often times students who need tutoring dont understand how the tutoring center works, so they just stand around instead of asking for help. Sometimes they ask questions as the tutors are about to leave, which is a pain.

review_title: The faculty are high quality but the financial support is poor.
job_title: Graduate Student in La Jolla, CA
pros: The faculty are generally excellent researchers. The graduate students are also fairly strong. It's a beautiful place to live of course and the campus is right near the beach.
cons: Wages are low and the cost of living is high. Student health makes it very hard to schedule appointments. It's very hard to get around the city without a car.

review_title: Excellent place to work and learn
job_title: Undergraduate Research Assistant in La Jolla, CA
pros: Very good place to gain research experience while earning some cash if you are a student here, as this is regarded as a top research institution. People are very nice, friendly and easy to work with.
cons: You don't get paid much for being a part time undergraduate researcher. You may need to figure of lot of the things out by yourself because no one in the lab has such background to help you.

review_title: A nice university with good basic science in a prime location.
job_title: Postdoctoral Fellow in La Jolla, CA
pros: The level of academic researchers is overall high, due to the immense appeal of the area. UCSD doesn't have to work too hard to attract bright researches that would love to live in a great location with a perfect climate.
cons: The parking situation is outrageous, staff has to buy overpriced parking permits which don't guarantee a spot. There were agreements that allowed staff to use campus-bound MTS buses (local transportation companies) which were recently unilaterally revoked.

job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in San Diego, CA
pros: The quality and quantity of research being done at UCSD is fantastic. Great location. Most employees are really intelligent and competent. Campus-wide communication is good--for example, employees are always notified in advance before construction work.
cons: Parking is really expensive. Internally, there are lots of bureaucratic hurdles, especially when it comes to finding the right person to do something or answer a certain question.

job_title: in San Diego, CA
pros: I get a lot of intellectual freedom from my advisor to pursue the project that I want to. As a result I have a positive outlook on my research.
cons: Race relations on campus can be touchy. There is very little sense of community and there is greater responsibility upon the students to find the circles that support them.

review_title: Received my graduate degree and had ample freedom to interact across departments with my doctoral research.
job_title: Graduate Student in La Jolla, CA
pros: Typical pros of graduate school apply here: freedom to explore intellectual topics of interest, reasonably flexible work hours, work environment with many smart people.
cons: Typical cons of graduate school apply here: low pay and disconnect from what happens outside the ivory tower. From my experiences the graduate programs at UCSD (speaking from my experience, although this may be extendable to many other schools, as well) is evolving to train/*encourage* students to work outside academia at the rate that is needed.

review_title: I was in grad school. It's never easy.
job_title: Graduate Student in La Jolla, CA
pros: UCSD has a supportive work environment, motivated researchers, and is an excellent academic school. I enjoyed my time there.
cons: There doesn't seem to be a lot of organization in training for teaching. The grad students in my department were given exactly 6 hours of training over the course of a year, so the day they started teaching classes they had only 2 hours of teacher training under their belts. Not enough prep for the working environment. Tons of focus on research detracts from a quality teaching environment.

review_title: Pays the bills so you can study or do research.
job_title: Teaching Assistant in La Jolla, CA
pros:
Pretty campus.

Can take up very little time and hours are fairly flexible.

Teaching makes you learn the material better.

Some students and fellow TAs are extremely smart and give deeper insights.
cons:
Parking is expensive and hard to find and campus is not particularly bike friendly either.

Students are often unresponsive and antisocial, which doesn't always make for the best atmosphere.

Working for the wrong professor can ruin the experience.

Sometimes employed simply as a homework 'answer machine,' which is a waste of time for both students and TAs.

review_title: Rethink your decision to work at UCSD
job_title: Anonymous Employee in La Jolla, CA
pros: I have work here for over 8 years...the only pro to working here is they can't fire you if you are part of a union.
cons:
Where to begin???
Parking is $81 a month and there is no where to park
No substainal raises..if you are okay with .50 cents an hour. 
Union dues that does nothing
Crappy management 
Nepotism galore! 
No room for growth within your department
Horrible traffic to UCSD
Required furloughs, however upper management make lots of money and always construction. No Christmas bonuses. No paid pregnancy leave if you don't have sdi. Since when is giving birth a disability? Also, salary is a lot more in private sector. They don't care about employees because we are replaceable.

job_title: Setup and Field Lining Coordinator in La Jolla, CA

review_title: Active campus, research seems to be spread thin"
job_title: Anonymous Employee in La Jolla, CA
pros: "Diverse/Creative student body. Great weather and near the beach. Tons of activities/events on campus. Competitive atmosphere in a healthy way. There are a lot of resources on campus to help students with professional development.”
cons: "Tuition is growing each year. It is hard to really get anything stuff done without a ton of paperwork to follow. Parking is becoming more expensive and very difficult to find. Lab spaces can be pretty tight and equipment can be dated"

job_title: Postdoctoral Scholar in San Diego, CA
pros: flexible time management, young environment, location, challenges every day, future perspectives if you make it here and work very very hard
cons: the salary, pressure, social environment, bad work life balance if you are in the wrong department, depending on the PI

review_title: Bureaucracy can get in the way sometimes
job_title: Anonymous Employee in La Jolla, CA
pros: Excellent benefits. Dependable schedule. Opportunities to grow and learn professionally. Academia environment. Invested in employee health and well-being.
cons: While there are benefits, you have to search for them. Outdated systems can be an embarrassment when dealing with students in one of the top-rated CSE programs in the country. Depending upon department, can be difficult to move up ladder.  Much is dependent on retirements. Overall, it's a big system and you need to find your own way and niche to thrive.

job_title: Research Assistant in La Jolla, CA
pros:
As a student I have been guaranteed a flexible schedule that accommodates my class load.

I have been able to use my major and apply it to a real life position as a research assistant.

UCSD is committed to helping students succeed after graduation.
cons:
Students cannot work more than 20 hours per week while enrolled in classes.

There hasn't been a ton of room for growth since students cannot be promoted to certain staff positions.

review_title: Not the time of my life work-wise, but does anyone love being a postdoc?
job_title: Postdoctoral Scholar in La Jolla, CA
pros: This obviously one of the top universities for biomedical research and it's great to be doing science in a place surrounded by very knowledgeable people who are at the top of their field.
cons: Crummy compensation and benefits for postdocs, expensive hard-to-find parking, something is always on construction and causing lots of noise.

job_title: Graduate Student in La Jolla, CA
pros: The research at UCSD is top-notch. Close collaboration with neighboring Institutes, like the Salk and others, make it a great place to do research. The graduate community is a close-knit group and events for the students are held throughout the year. And of course the location is beautiful, and within a short distance to the beach and downtown.

review_title: I like working for UC San Diego

review_title: Great institution, but does not pay its Teaching Assistants well enough
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in San Diego, CA

job_title: Research Assistant IV in La Jolla, CA

job_title: PhD Student/Researcher in San Diego, CA
pros: Very good at ensuring funding for students whether through TAships or grants or fellowships. Nearly everyone I knew had stable funding of some kind.

review_title: HDH - Bistro - Good on campus Job

review_title: Great place to learn, experiement, in a great location
job_title: Mechanical Engineer in La Jolla, CA

a few of the labs are small, so you have a chance to develop a very broad skillset

great place for interns as well!

job_title: Student Services Office Assistant in Lynwood, CA

job_title: in San Diego, CA

This is practice is a shell-game, moving money from one department to another so taxpayers will never know how much is being spent by a particular department.

review_title: This job really is what you make it

review_title: Not a bad place to work.

review_title: Excellent Part-Time Job for University Students

job_title: Programmer Analyst in La Jolla, CA

review_title: temps are a dime a dozen

review_title: Great place to work - especially as a stepping stone
job_title: Student Lab Assistant in La Jolla, CA
pros:
This position allowed me to work with some of the best and most knowledgeable people in the field.
This job inspired me to pursue my masters.
cons:
Work life balance was not that great. 
Time not spent in class were spent at work. Felt pressure to come and work when not in class.

job_title: in La Jolla, CA
pros: overall an excellent place to work. Sometimes it can be a little difficult to work for such a large government institution though
cons: sort of already mentioned the large government institution thing. But other than that parking can sometimes be a nightmare. Students can be difficult but still way better than average

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in San Diego, CA
pros: TA work is fun and a very gratifying part of graduate school. There are teaching awards for the highest performers, but more structured mentorship of grad students in teaching roles would be a win win.
cons: Not the easiest place to get rich. Can be difficult to connect with students in certain majors, as motivation varies considerably, even in advanced classes

review_title: Great place to work while in school
job_title: Facilities Supervisor in La Jolla, CA
pros:
- flexible work hours
- friendly staff and co workers
- pay is good 
- as a first job UCSD is a great place to start for many students
cons: - not really for professional resume; since many of the jobs are part time jobs for students to help them financially, it's mainly as a part time job to earn side money

review_title: Good stable job but not much room to grow
job_title: Senior Artist in San Diego, CA
pros:
Feels like a great place to work if you're settled down.

• Calm work environment
• Stable job
• Good benefits
• The majority of employees are pleasant people to be around
cons:
Not a lot of opportunities to stretch skills / abilities for those eager to try new things.

• Very corporate atmosphere with a lot of bureaucracy / red tape
• Not much room for career growth

job_title: ESL Instructor in San Diego, CA
pros: you are usually left alone to teach as you see fit so they trust you as an Instructor.
cons: You never know if you will have any hours from one quarter to the next.  Also, you are expected to work more hours than you get paid for.  Management can be unsupportive and and sometimes bitchy.

job_title: Postdoctoral Fellow in La Jolla, CA
pros: Being a postdoc at UC San Diego is a great occasion if you are coming from abroad to boost your academic career, and to have a chance to build your network in US.
cons: The problem is that you remain in this position for many years, and often you do not have a chance to get an academic job.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in San Diego, CA
pros: Good weather, close to the cliffs, good academic environment, many interesting events, an opportunity to meet people from all over the world
cons: Parking is expensive unless you are willing to walk a long way, buildings are not easy to navigate, otherwise nothing to complain about

job_title: Financial Analyst II in La Jolla, CA
pros: Good benefits.   Great campus environment.
cons: Bad commute.  Parking is hard.  You have to pay to park there.  No real annual pay increases unless you get reclassified.  Many jobs have unions that take a cut of your paycheck.  Advancement is hard.

job_title: Undergraduate Researcher in La Jolla, CA
pros: I found it really easy to simply reach out to individuals (professors and labs) conducting research I found interesting and they were very open to having me on board to join them with pay. It’s a great experience for any student and looks good on a resume. It’s also a great way to find mentors to write future letters of rec.
cons: Your research doesn’t typically go anywhere unless you put in a lot of time and effort for it.

review_title: Flexible, great hours, great bosses and coworkers
job_title: Research Desk Assistant in La Jolla, CA
pros: The supervisor and head librarian are so sweet and understanding. They genuinely are about your wellbeing, and are very flexible with your hours (as long as a co-worker covers the shift, you can switch it out). Bi-annual birthday parties where the bosses bring in cake and food for you- it's really a lovely gesture.
cons: You have weekly and bi-weekly tasks, but nothing out of hand or out of the ordinary.

job_title: Postdoctoral Scholar in San Diego, CA
pros: Flexible schedule, interesting research, excellent colleagues
cons: Being a postdoc is ridiculously stressful. The fact is that most postdocs are hoping they will become research faculty, and most of them will not be successful. The pressure is intense. I loved being a graduate student. As always, your PI has an insane amount of power over you. So be very, very careful about doing your research ahead of time (check with their grad students, hopefully also grad students not in their group also).

job_title: Laboratory Assistant I in San Diego, CA
pros: The benefits offered are great-- even if you are only employed part time (but at least 17.5 hours per week).
cons: The pay is low, but that's not the university's fault-- it's due to cuts in federal funding. Likewise, job security is unknown as the funding situation is unknown from year to year. Keep in mind that the pay for this position may vary depending on the department you work for (some departments are better funded than others).

review_title: CSE Research at UCSD gives one the opportunity to be in close contact with both the academia and industry.
job_title: Research Assistant in La Jolla, CA
pros: Very interesting projects, opportunity for good collaborations. Great location and great people to work with. And quite importantly, flexible hours. Huge amount of activities when outside the office.
cons: The first research project one picks is usually not a process done with great care, and at times projects may not overlap with the expertise of the student, which may consume an unwanted long time.

job_title: Laboratory Assistant in San Diego, CA
pros: Work was M-F. No weekends or overtime. Although salaries were low, benefits were generous and if you worked there throughout your career, you earned a pension. Jobs were plentiful and transfers were available.
cons: Employees had to pay for parking, which was expensive. Parking was shared with graduate students, medical students, and faculty so spaces were limited. The hiring process was lengthy and even though there was ample room for advancement, the hiring/transfer process was lengthy and somewhat inefficient.

job_title: Undergraduate Research Assistant in La Jolla, CA
pros: Good Research Atmosphere. Get to work with top scientists in their field, not just from UCSD but from many great institutions in the US and abroad.
cons: The nearby area can be expensive to live in, but I was easily able to commute using the extensive shuttle system on campus.

job_title: Caterer in La Jolla, CA
pros:
*Simple and easy hiring process
*mostly friendly co-workers, supervisors, and managers
*great on the job training
*free meals
cons:
*Understaffed, workplace was often hectic, barely any time for a lunch break sometimes
*If you are student, be prepared to dedicate nearly all of your time outside of classes for this job; wouldn't recommended for students who care a lot about academics 
*Finding a place to park at some delivery sites was often problematic, wish there were more reserved places for delivery vehicles

review_title: Takes a special type of personality to work here
job_title: Director, IT Systems in La Jolla, CA
pros:
- Work life balance
- Absolutely no deadlines
cons:
- No accountability, it's everyone else's problem
- Frustrating to people who want to see things move forward or succeed
- Waste, waste, waste.

review_title: In the heart of La Jolla, UC San Diego is a great place for the perfect blend of academia and the outdoors.
job_title: Financial Analyst in La Jolla, CA
pros: The weather is great. The people are very academic and into what they are doing. People are friendly. The pay is usually fair.
cons: Lack of social-life. The campus can be extremely quiet at times. The food on campus can be improved, and it is difficult to navigate the campus both due to its large size and its many hills.

job_title: Office Assistant in La Jolla, CA
pros:
Benefits: Health insurance, automatic retirement fund.
Extremely convenient for on campus students or anyone living nearby. 
Very flexible with school schedule.
cons:
Pay for student is rarely above minimum wage. Despite this they still expect salary/full-time quality. 
Since there is a lot of job variety, it is very hit or miss with both good pairing with your skill as well as quality of the job posted.

review_title: I worked in Student Affairs at UCSD
job_title: Special Assistant to AVC, Admissions and Enrollment in San Diego, CA
pros: My specific department was full of professional, hardworking employees. For the most part, we worked regular hours, and the workload was not overwhelming, unless during a special event.
cons: The parking is insane. The room for growth was not apparent. The staff seems to keep jobs for a very long time.

job_title: Programmer Analyst in San Diego, CA
pros:
Working atmosphere is very casual. The 'corporate culture' is very relaxed. 
Not too much stress aside from the slow career progression.
 Academic and research culture keeps it interesting.
Generous vacation and holiday days off.
cons:
Pay scale feels incredibly low as budget is low due to lack of funding or extreme mismanagement of financials. 
Managers often promoted to position of least effectiveness and not properly trained. Very wasteful fiscally
Noncompetitive atmosphere leads to lackadaisical attitude, unmotivated staff.

job_title: Hospital Assistant in San Diego, CA
pros: Benefits are good.  Just about that, though.
cons:
All of the deductions you get per pay check.  I was making about 25 dollars an hour, and one of my bi-weekly check was what a minimum wage job position made.  
Salary increases are a joke.  Supervisors are trained to confuse employees into making them think that they cannot give you a raise because the unions don't allow it--BS.  UC regents are just becoming the greediest folks like most corporate America now in days.  
Apply elsewhere.  With this company, you will only work with unscrupulous supervisors, and low wages.

job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in La Jolla, CA
pros: The directors of the graduate program I was in were extremely supportive of their students, and they were responsive to any issues that students brought up. Although I didn't particularly like the lab I was in (off-campus), I had no doubt that the leadership of my graduate program would have my back.
cons: Parking on-campus is expensive and hard to find. This cost is an extra burden for graduate students commuting distances to work on campus.

review_title: A great job to do on the side while studying
job_title: Shuttle Driver in La Jolla, CA
pros:
Very easy to change shifts
Seeing more of the campus and San Diego area
Fully paid training and testing
Enjoyable work and great co-workers
Getting a Class B license
Supervisors are quite understanding 
A lot of personal responsibility
cons:
May have to work a few 6:30 shifts in the beginning
Getting caught in traffic often
Dealing with broken down vehicles

review_title: Flexible Lab experience under great Primary Investigators.
job_title: Lab Manager in San Diego, CA
pros: The best part of working on campus is the flexibility.  I can maintain work hours on my own time between classes.  I also enjoy the experience in the lab.  Great refinances.
cons: There is not much room for growth.  This is not a career job.  Better for networking with up and coming academic stars interested in research.  Overly bureaucratic environment with trouble between inter office rivalries.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in San Diego, CA
pros: UCSD have good vibes.  Except for the interesting research, UCSD provides many courses, workshops and seminars to upgrade your knowledge. One can do much collaboration, which are very favorable around the UCSD labs. UCSD have the best health care plan.
cons: Facilities do need some upgrades.

job_title: Processing Assistant in La Jolla, CA
pros: Worked in undergraduate admissions. My direct supervisor was awesome. Very understanding of a student's schedule. The work being asked was easy to learn and comprehend. The office almost always had food to share with its student workers.
cons: A lot of the staff workers would use the student workers to find out about gossip or would use them to undermine another staff worker that they did not work. Did not create a pleasant atmosphere at work some times.

job_title: Administrative Assistant in San Diego, CA
pros: Benefits are great, retirement is among the best, campus is beautiful, lots of holidays, smoke free environment, good public transit
cons: Parking fees are way too high and there are no spaces to be had anyway. Pay stagnates when the state budget goes down.

job_title: Research Assistant in La Jolla, CA
pros: Everything. Environment is relaxing. People here are so laid-back and nice. Administration is efficient. And the pay is satisfactory for a grad student.
cons: None! Seriously, I can't think of anything ... Nothing to complain about. Maybe ... the gym can be bigger?

job_title: Social Media Coordinator in San Diego, CA
pros: Lots of wonderful projects requiring individual initiative and/or team work.
cons: Management is overpaid and separated from team members.  Definite lack of communication and very much a "Do as I say, not as I do" attitude.  Some evidence of racism and other discriminatory practices not befitting a major university.

job_title: Postdoctoral Scholar in San Diego, CA
pros: Salaries and benefits for postdocs, seems to be constantly improving. Salary undergoes (modest) increases yearly. After the 1st year of work, the minimum contract length is 2 years, substantial personal time-off (vacations), sick leave, maternity or paternity leave (compared to other academic institutions) and pretty good healthcare cover.
cons: It can improve in terms of structure and organisation. At times it seems disjointed (groups with disparate research topics share lab space) and inefficient in promoting cross-talk and collaborations.

job_title: Research Assistant in La Jolla, CA
pros: To get an undergraduate research assistant job, all you have to do is do well in courses, engage with professors, be persistent, and work hard.  Then you get to work on interesting projects that will pay you as well as provide good experience for grad school or industry
cons: The bureaucracy permeates everything.  Half of my lab manager's job is fighting with UCSD management.

job_title: Customer Service Representative/Events Representative in San Diego, CA
pros:
Friendly management and staff
Access to concerts and different events on campus that the general student population may not even know about 
Good training system
cons:
Hours change every week
The job requires you to work late nights at times and there could be a lot of pressure involved for customer service

review_title: Great location. Close to the ocean
job_title: in San Diego, CA
pros: Great benefits.one of the few companies with a pension. Cutting edge medical research and science, great lcation and close to the ocean
cons: Not a lot of diversity in work/practical experience.  Large  population of the staff graduate from UCSD and work there their entire careers.

job_title: Biomedical Science PhD Candidate in La Jolla, CA
pros: The quality of research being done here is excellent! Many opportunities to grow in techniques and understanding. Hours can be long but are flexible. Former coworkers from industry now work here, and report better pay.
cons: The depth of work may make it difficult to meet new people, network, or expand areas of personal interest into new topics of study.

job_title: Resident Advisor in La Jolla, CA
pros: Great job. The staff is wonderful. The assistant deans truly care about their resident advisors. Provide resources to college students such as counseling and psychological services
cons: There has been an increase in program demand. The number of required programs has increased by 100 percent. Also there has been a new implementation of late night events that require resident advisors to work from 11pm to 2am. However the events are fun and engaging and on weekends.

review_title: Fantastic graduate school to attend to, mutiple disciplinary projects are reachable with amazing educational sources.
job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in La Jolla, CA
pros: The school provides all kinds of different opportunities to get involved in related research based on what group you join, and how your advisor's style of cultivating students.
cons: There might be no work-life balance if you meet a bad advisor, and it's totally depend on what adivsor you get, so be sharp in selecting an advisor.

job_title: Student Office Assistant in San Diego, CA
pros: Flexible schedule and friendly student workers.
cons:
Regulations for parking always change without fully you receiving the full details or without being properly informed. 
Staff can be cranky. 
Pay should be increased.

job_title: Legal Secretary in San Diego, CA
pros: Great place to work: employees are kind, respectful, happy to have you there.  Really great perqs such as retirement, paid time off, health insurance. Wonderful employer.
cons: I worked as a temporary employee but was hoping to get an offer of full-time employment. It didn't come before a private firm offered me a job or I might still be there.

job_title: CSE Tutor in San Diego, CA
pros: UCSD is well known for their engineering, so working in the cse department means you will be in good hands.
cons: I feel like they have enough money to pay more. Every year they get hella donation but i don't know where it goes because they are not making the department bigger.

job_title: Student Involvement Leadership Consultant in La Jolla, CA
pros: Absolutely amazing CSI program. I loved working there. Everyone is such a family and you actually feel like your supervisors care about YOU and not just what you put into the job. They sincerely care for your future well-being and career path.
cons: I can't think of a single thing in terms of the CSI's SILC program. I am not rating the university, but just UCSD's Center for Student Involvement/University Centers division.

job_title: Research Assistant in La Jolla, CA
pros: Work was very flexible with hours-- did not interfere with my personal schedule at all.  Professor was invested in work we did, and gave regular check-ins and feedback on what we provided.
cons: Very uncoordinated in regards to coworkers-- only ever spoke to one other and had no idea who was working on what.  However, this did not interfere much with what I was assigned.

job_title: Corporate Relations Student Assistant in La Jolla, CA
pros: I worked for Corporate Relations at Jacobs School of Engineering. The work environment was excellent, and my managers treated me with extreme kindness and understanding. Very flexible work hours, was always well fed and hydrated during work. There was also lots of time to work on homework during shifts. The management was the best part of the job!
cons: Number of shifts available can vary depending how busy the quarter is for recruitment.

job_title: Bioengineering PhD Student in San Diego, CA
pros: Strong program, good professors who care about the students. Classes are interesting and require you to stay on top of things.
cons: The faculty does not provide that much one on one interaction with the students as this is a public school. Also it is hard to truly understand and appreciate the major because classes are so eclectic: biomolecular techniques, fluid dynamics, thermodynamics, electronics as well as programming are all part of the fare.

job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in San Diego, CA
pros: Well i dont know what to say. this place really has a good brand name. depending on the major, the job scene is quite good too. i guess that's pretty much it.
cons: Um, I guess the worst thing in my opinion would be the ancient administration. There has to be a way for students to provide safe feedback about the administration, department officials, heads, faculty, courses, without risking losing anything in the process

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Seattle, WA
pros: met with professor on the weekly basis and develop the course learning plan, hold lab hour and help students go over the problems.
cons: class size is very big at UCSD. sometimes lots of students did not come to the discussion since it is not mandatory.

job_title: Desktop Support Technician in La Jolla, CA
pros: Really nice people to work with. Teach you the basic ropes and show you the glimpsed of real world function. People there used to work for the big companies, show they applied their knowledge to the department.
cons: Salary. I understand that it's a student job, but when the shuttle driver is making more than you.... there's need to be some change.

job_title: SRA II in La Jolla, CA
pros: Great benefits and depending on the department that you're in, there is usually opportunities for advancement. Plenty of beneficial training opportunities is readily available to employees.
cons: They way UCSD policy works, it's very hard to "fire" someone after they've been with the University for a while and have passed their probation period. For this reason, some employees and management have stayed on longer than they probably should.

job_title: Manager in San Diego, CA
pros: Fun team to work with.  Directly supervise others.  Culture and values of employees are aligned with mission- wanting to help others, serve patients, and bring new therapies to the field.  Lots of things to be done, so you are responsible for many different things- great learning opportunity.
cons: Pay, sometimes difficult to navigate the system.  Long time to implement changes.

job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in La Jolla, CA
pros: Great City. Fair and above average pay. Kind PI. Departments care about the graduate students.
cons: Campus is literally socially dead. Very very difficult to find new friends. Only a few socializing/mixer events throughout the year.

job_title: Grad Student Researcher in San Diego, CA
pros: great location, top-notch core facilities, access to nearby facilities at Salk, TSRI, and Sanford
cons: PI's basically get to be little dictators of their labs, funding status of labs is hard to figure out from the outside and can turn on a dime, University Admin is very blue-skies in trying to become a top research institute.  Some people have been kept long past their usefulness

job_title: Postdoctoral Scholar and Adjunct Lecturer in La Jolla, CA
pros: Stimulating work environment, world-class research facilities, beautiful location, good benefits, many opportunities if you know the right people (it's all about the network)
cons: Post-doctoral Association does not have significant funding, many opportunities if you know the right people (it's all about the network)

job_title: Anonymous Employee in La Jolla, CA
pros: UC San Diego has really good benefits- no monthly deductions for dental & vision. Has everything you need on campus: gym, post office/passport office, great restaurants, access to library, discounts to shows/amusement parks and more! Many opportunities for growth if you're in the right field.
cons: Salary is usually on the low end. Parking is really expensive and not enough parking spaces- not many city transit options.

job_title: Postdoctoral Fellow in San Diego, CA
pros: Working as a postdoctoral fellow or scholar at UCSD is great because the benefits are good, there are great neuroscience labs, and the community of scientists are a great resource.
cons: As with any postdoc position, you want to move onto the next stage of your career so need to find a lab environment in which you can publish some papers and move on. This experience will vary depending on your personal situation/project.

job_title: Research Assistant in San Diego, CA
pros: Meaningful work with intelligent, motivated and helpful people. Amazing location right on the beach. Many interesting events, conferences and seminars on the campus daily. Active community involvement and discounts to the Birch Aquarium for Scripps affiliation.
cons: Student and employment positions are competitive. Parking is limited to street parking, car break-ins occur occasionally. Low/fixed pay in entry level or student positions. Overall experience can vary greatly depending on supervisor/PI or department.

job_title: Research Technician in La Jolla, CA
pros: The location, facilities, and research at UCSD are all top-notch.  I had no complaints while I was working there.
cons: Although I did not have to deal with it directly, I heard from the person who dealt with my hiring paperwork that coordinating with HR there can be a bit of a hassle.

job_title: Postdoctoral Scholar in San Diego, CA
pros: Have worked at UC San Diego as a researcher for 10 years and currently a postdoctoral Scholar in the biomedical sciences. Love how many research labs exist on such a big campus and how collaborative all of the PIs are. Will never get bored of research and always a lab to fit your interest. Often flexible hours as well.
cons: Pay is through NIH scaling for Postdocs so as usual underpaid :(

review_title: Odd hours, poor training at UCSD Box Office
job_title: Senior Event Manager in La Jolla, CA
pros: The UCSD Box Office has interesting people (all students, naturally), but is definitely focused on throwing people in the thick of things with minimal training. Some people like that.
cons: Lack of training and lack of cohesive communication between management and employees makes it stressful and really difficult to work without feeling like you're doing something wrong.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in La Jolla, CA
pros: Nice campus, great coworkers.  Good benefits.  Good work life balance.
cons: Very easy for staff to get comfortable, stagnant, yet still ride the system and get promotions.  Because of this there are a lot of staff who have been there a long time just "hanging out" in upper level positions.  Hard to get a position, and limited upward mobility once you are hired, even with appropriate experience and education.

review_title: Stable employment but very limited upward mobility.
job_title: Staff Research Associate II in San Diego, CA
pros: Working at UCSD has some great perks such as benefits, time off, a pension plan, etc...  The jobs tend to not be very stressful.
cons: Upward mobility is very difficult.  They have minimal step increases (which are less than the cost-of living increases) that occur for everyone, regardless of productivity.  This is not a good place for someone who is ambitious about their career.

job_title: Assistant Adjunct Professor in La Jolla, CA
pros: The weather is nice. The vacation policies and retirement package are good.
cons: Academics must get funding for their own salary by grants and contracts. The leadership focuses on protecting their own and maintaining the status quo at the expense of early career academics. The reputation for scientific excellence is not entirely warranted. The students don't get a great education.

review_title: A decent place for a student employee
job_title: Anonymous Employee in La Jolla, CA
pros: Good side benefits for student employees - priority registration is very useful. Decent compensation. Mostly functional leadership. Lots of good people.
cons: The parking situation is lousy, regardless of your level of employment. Hours limits for students. Sometimes the amount of bureaucracy can be annoying.

job_title: Staff Research Associate I in San Diego, CA
pros: Academia research, more freedom, better environment for innovation
cons: Low pay, not much room for growth if your PI doesn't get grants, can be laid off anytime

review_title: Great place to pursue a PHD and live a life
job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in La Jolla, CA
pros: Academic strength is superb at ECE department. Good facilities, good company relations, good reputations.
cons: Need to devote a lot of time, weekend, nights doing jobs. Sometimes it‘s hard and frustrating. But that's the way PHD should experience.

review_title: I loved working at this company. They really support their employees
job_title: Staff RN in San Diego, CA
pros: Great teamwork, the managers are awesome, they really support research. People are very nice and they really care about the patients
cons: It is unionize so if you don't like unions this is not the place for you. Mandatory union dues even if you don't even support

job_title: Temporary Employment in La Jolla, CA
pros: UC San Diego has a bunch of great departments to work with and they match to a position based on your skills and take into account what you want. Also great opportunity to get a full time, permanent position.
cons: You won't get benefits until after 2 months and may have to take a couple weeks off in between assignments.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in La Jolla, CA
pros: The ability to improve your teaching skills with the faculty is outstanding. It really allows you to work on your interpersonal skills since you have to deal with students and faculty at the same time. The work is very rewarding ultimately.
cons: Sometimes the work exceeds the allowable work amounts which can get frustrating. If you dont have any connections with a Professor it may be difficult to get hired.

review_title: Great Place to work if you are a student.
job_title: in San Diego, CA
pros: flexible hours, real work experience. they treat you like you are a real person instead of a run of the mill student worker. easily translates into a full time position
cons: the pay is not great. especially if you land a full time job after graduation. There are definitely other places with better pay

job_title: Postdoctoral Researcher in La Jolla, CA
pros: My positions is very flexible and I get to work with instruments that few people will have the opportunity to work with.
cons: I'm not sure where my current work will lead me. My position may not be typical, ever lab is different but I usually work allow with very little input from my supervisor.

job_title: Research Assistant/Teaching Assistant in San Diego, CA
pros: UCSD is a top notch institute with vibrant student body and faculty. It's quite competitive, but stimulating. Student Affairs staff is friendly and helpful. As a teaching assistant I found that I had to put in a lot more hours than the 20 hours per week in my contract. The students are smart but they are very demanding, as they should be.
cons: Union agreements, compensation, parking arrangements.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in La Mesa, CA
pros: Great benefits and flexible schedule.  The campus is a collaborative environment that constantly expanding!
cons: pay is not close to market.  The area around UCSD is expensive so commuting is necessary...

job_title: in La Jolla, CA
pros: Schedule is flexible; supervisor is very friendly and supportive; wage is high compared to other on-campus jobs
cons: Some students may come to ask non-calculus questions which are usually hard; few tutors were not working during their hours

job_title: Applications Developer in La Jolla, CA
pros: Great benefits package, friendly people, plenty of opportunities to learn and network, beautiful location, employee discount at the on campus food court.
cons: Low pay, expensive parking, expensive public transportation options, parking is shared with the graduate students, food options on campus aren't that great.

review_title: Great environment for those comfortable in an academic setting.
job_title: in La Jolla, CA
pros: The benefits are great since you're working for an academic institution.  The work is usually intellectually stimulating.  On occasion there is seemingly too much red tape.
cons: The university is a rather large bureaucracy which can be very frustrating at times.

job_title: Data Processing Assistant in La Jolla, CA
pros: Flexible hours, decent pay, entry level research job for a college student. I like the work environment because it is relaxed and I can get my work done. Great location right off of La Jolla Shores. I can see the ocean from my building.
cons: I do data processing which is pretty basic so I do the same tasks everyday. I don't talk to my supervisor very often.

job_title: Student Involvement Leadership Consultant in San Diego, CA
pros:
- Great school to go to, especially for research
- Amazing colleagues who push you to be better
- Balance of school, work, and life is easier in this environment
cons:
- For those not into research and/or engineering, it's a bit hard to find your niche
- Schoolwork can take a toll on your other endeavors

review_title: Fun, loved the college atmosphere, and surprisingly strict
job_title: Swim Instructor in La Jolla, CA
pros:
Coworkers are great since they're also students, nice way to branch out and get to know people outside of your usual social circles
Pay is reasonable and making some pocket money helps
cons: Just got to balance out academics and work and don't slack off on either

job_title: GSR in San Diego, CA
pros: Lots of exciting science going on.  Collaboration across departments gives this university a big advantage in the research field.  There is a lot of good work going on here and it is a much less competitive environment than on the east coast.
cons: Pay is limited to set pay scales.  Administration is a bit bloated and simple things like hiring can become difficult.

review_title: Would highly recommend working as a student for this department on campus
job_title: Office Assistant and Peer Adviser in San Diego, CA
pros: Friendly counselors, flexible hours, chill work enviornment. Any student who has participated in AIP would be fully qualified for the job. Peer advising and running orientations is a good way to improve public speaking skills. Opportunities to pick up extra paid hours at events are nice.
cons: Sometimes boring and slow especially in the middle of the quarter

job_title: Transportation Specialist in La Jolla, CA
pros: UC San Diego has a good working environment, flexible hours, co-workers are great people, and the pay is good for a student.
cons: The shifts are preassigned each quarter based on your schedule, not really your preference.

job_title: Asset Management Intern in La Jolla, CA

review_title: Poor pay, no raises, no respect
job_title: Senior Administrative Analyst in La Jolla, CA
pros: A sense of purpose -- you are supporting students and learning. Unlike the corporate world, there is at least lip service given to "community."
cons: The Chancellor and Vice Chancellors are preoccupied with attracting respected faculty (and paying them large amounts), and recruiting high-profile donors. Staff people are not respected or supported. We have not had raises in about 10 years, and staff positions are not filled when people leave, meaning there is more work for everyone. There have been small raises (1-3% in the past few years BUT these are offset by increased payroll deductions for the previously mismanaged pension fund. You must pay $1000/year for parking, but if you do not arrive on campus by 7:30am, you will need to park across the freeway and walk or shuttle (adding 20-30 more minutes on to your commute each way). You cannot leave during the day for an errand or doctor appointment, because there will be no place to park when you return. Hundreds more parking spots are disappearing each year over the next few years, so it will only get worse. Unless you are taking a very high management or faculty position, you will be asked to continually "tighten your belt." Before accepting any position or salary, be sure to ask about the mandatory payroll deductions for the pension, parking, and medical insurance plans. Ask what the raises have been for staff in the department over the past 5yrs. This may be a place for a worker just out of school to gain experience -- but I would not advise anyone else to take a position here. If you think you want the job to get your foot in the door, and believe that your hard work and dedication will surely get you a quick raise or promotion, you will be mistaken. Things don't work like that here.

job_title: Staff Research Associate II in San Diego, CA

cons: Winter break mandatory off, but not compensated. Although, you are able to apply saved up vacation hours to the mandatory time off.

review_title: Student Health Sevices - Not Exactly Great
job_title: Optometrist in San Diego, CA
pros: Pretty easy going management there
cons:
Have to pay for your own parking! expensive- long way from the clinic
No benefits- had to pay for my own pre employment lab tests
No advancement opportunities
low pay

job_title: Principal Animal Technician in San Diego, CA

cons: The vast experience, knowledge, skills, methods, theories learned in this institution will make one valuable, competitive, and skilled in this profession.

job_title: Postdoctoral Scholar in La Jolla, CA

cons: High cost of living in La Jolla. Need to drive everywhere. UC mandates taking a portion of salary for retirement. Not good for people just getting out of grad school who need the money.

review_title: Working here has changed my life for the better.
job_title: Registered Nurse in La Jolla, CA

cons: They got rid of a pension plan but still a good place to work at. Gotta be able to deal with rude people

job_title: Producer/Director in San Diego, CA
pros: Great people to work with.
cons: No room for growth, understaffed, management needs to listen to the needs of their employees, union contract negotiations needs to be met.There's a gender and race wage disparity and discrimination that needs to be fixed.  People in the top are taking advantage of workers.

review_title: Great benefits, nice people to work with, management needs training
job_title: Program Manager in La Jolla, CA
pros:
- great benefits
- nice people to work with 
- free classes
cons:
- low pay
- most positions are dead end
- management does not know how to lead or inspire employees 
- office politics and not a merit based system

review_title: This job is probably the best on campus job. You don't interact with too many students, and the staff is great!
job_title: Circulation Assistant in San Diego, CA
pros: Kind supervisors, promotes movement (pushing carts, carrying books)
cons: Needed to work at least to closing shifts which were at midnight, however the supervisors were very understanding if this couldn't be met for a good reason

review_title: Seems like a standard university organization; not much in structural prioritization of students
job_title: Department Assistant in La Jolla, CA

cons: Upper management makes no effort to connect with, support, or protect, student workers

review_title: Good management, just not enough hours
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Diego, CA

cons: They just don't give a lot of hours, which unfortunately led me to let go of the job.

job_title: Survey Worker (Research Assistant) in La Jolla, CA

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in San Diego, CA

cons: Prepared homework, programming assignments, exams, and projects; kept records; distributed and copied reading materials; prepare answer keys and supplementary notes; and act as the course web-master.

job_title: Architect Drafter in La Jolla, CA

cons: Not much to learn from the job. Very difficult to get promoted.

job_title: CHEAR Research Assistant in San Diego, CA
pros: The people are friendly and welcoming, and the environment was very warm. I felt like I learned a lot at my job! The times were flexible as well.
cons: I really enjoyed my time at CHEAR, and I felt everything was very organized, so I don't have any cons at this point.

job_title: in La Jolla, CA
pros: Great benefits, nice coworkers, great environment. You have to work hard and always be innovative there. You need to look around for promotional opportunities.
cons: Not many cons, the uc retirement package was in trouble and with the state budget crisis there were pay cuts. That is always hard on moralle.

review_title: Prestigious institution with good support for graduate students
job_title: Teaching Assistant in La Jolla, CA
pros: Perfect weather, predictable schedule, and free tuition!
cons: Most of the class grading structure rewards students who care only about grades to solve problems but not understand subject matter.

review_title: Worked for UCSD for 1.5 years, treated poorly.
job_title: Administrative Assistant I in La Jolla, CA
pros:
Nice people
Job stability (this could go either way. Its literally impossible for even the most useless employees to lose their jobs)
cons:
Low pay
Low respect
No one ever gets fired, no one ever moves up in the company - where you are hired is where you will stay until you quit or die

review_title: Great quality clinical care, good place to work.
job_title: Genetic Counselor III Supv in San Diego, CA
pros: Very stable organization, providing solid clinical care. Great colleagues, lots of people stick around for vesting and benefits. Great place to work!
cons: Regimented salary and increases, leaving little room for significant negotiations. Union involvement slows things to a crawl. Parking for staff at Thornton hospital is lacking.

review_title: Good benefits, tons of red tape
job_title: Blank Assist II in La Jolla, CA

cons: I've worked in a few public universities, but the amount of time it takes to get anything done around here is staggering. Maybe it's a California thing.

job_title: Graduate Student in La Jolla, CA

cons: Parking is expensive and limited.  The campus feels isolated.   The hours can be long.  The pay is mediocre.  People are not always friendly.

job_title: Lab Assistant in La Jolla, CA
pros: Great people to work for if you are in the right department. The pay is commpetitive and the benfits for full-time is awesome.
cons: The parking is a nightmare and you either have to commute in or get to campus very early and pay $8 to park there all day.

job_title: Shuttle Driver in La Jolla, CA
pros: Its easy and everyone is nice. I like the fact that there is a lot of camaraderie among the student drivers.
cons: Its easy. Gets boring if you don't switch up your routes. Can also distract you from studying which can be an issue

review_title: Recreation department is a nice, laid back environment for students to have some fun!
job_title: Water Safety Instructor in La Jolla, CA

cons: Not enough hours per week

job_title: Grad Student in San Diego, CA
pros: Grad office staff was great and always helpful, and of course, UCSD is a world-class institution with very exciting research going on.
cons: Parking is expensive and difficult, and grad students are overworked, underpaid, and undersupported. But this is a general problem with grad school, not directly caused by UCSD.

job_title: Principal Radiologic Technologist in San Diego, CA

cons: Lots of politics and backstabbing.

review_title: If you do your job, it should be ok.
job_title: Senior Custodian in San Diego, CA
pros:
Good benefits
Variable hours
PPE provided
Shoes and uniforms proved makes it easier
cons:
The university can care more for the customer than the employee. 
Some custodians work more than others for same compensations.

review_title: Access to the smartest people in the world
job_title: Anonymous Employee in La Jolla, CA
pros: The university has the huge upside of being home to many of the smartest people in the sciences as well as one of the most ideal locations to work or study.
cons: A large, bureaucratic state university; lack of funding to compare with private universities

job_title: Research Data Analyst in San Diego, CA

cons:
Very underpaid in comparison to other members on my team who earn significantly more with less theoretical background and education.
No room for promotions unless someone resigns or retires

job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in San Diego, CA

-Excellent Resources
-New, rapidly growing department
-Lots of exciting research going on
-Pretty well funded department
cons:
-Low pay, but you already knew that if you're applying to grad school
-You're going to work veeeery hard if you want to succeed

job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in La Jolla, CA

job_title: PhD Student in La Jolla, CA

job_title: Teaching Assistant in La Jolla, CA

cons: You can not improve yourself in the teaching process. it's more like that you will waste a lot of your time on office hours and discussions.

review_title: Work as an statistician in the medical school.
job_title: Staff Research Associate II in La Jolla, CA

job_title: Executive Assistant in La Jolla, CA

job_title: Postdoctoral Researcher in San Diego, CA

review_title: Worked as a part time/work study at HDH
job_title: Anonymous Employee in La Jolla, CA
pros:
- on campus 
- easy to learn 
- can work with friends
- work study
cons:
- easy to get hurt 
- unfriendly student managers depending on different shifts
- not very considerate when trying to work around your classes

job_title: Ph D Graduate Student in La Jolla, CA

review_title: Great place to work for students

job_title: in La Jolla, CA

review_title: UCSD is great, but being a postdoc isn't
job_title: Postdoctoral Fellow in La Jolla, CA

review_title: Unfair, Poorly Trained, Management and Human Resource Department

review_title: Flexible hours, fantastic coworkers, boring work

job_title: Anonymous Employee in La Jolla, CA

review_title: If you are looking for good job stability and growth, UCSD is great.
job_title: Assistant in La Jolla, CA

cons:
- Upper management needs to be more organized

job_title: Postdoctoral Researcher in San Diego, CA

Benefits
People I work with (this can vary by dept.)
Great work/life balance

Parking is terrible
Not much nightlife around campus
Difficult to get around area (ie. one way in and one way out)

job_title: in San Diego, CA

The salary compensation is terrible compared to corporate organizations.

review_title: It's been a good place to stay as to seek for a PhD degree as well as to enjoy life.
job_title: Graduate Student in La Jolla, CA

review_title: Great university with excellent scientific research.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Diego, CA

review_title: Was a ta for the school

review_title: Great place to work for students

 Day care service. Flexible working hour and work load.

review_title: A way to fund your PhD
